Modern Coding Theory:
The Statistical Mechanics and Computer Science Point of View

Andrea Montanari1‚Äâ and R√ºdiger Urbanke2
1Stanford University, montanari@stanford.edu,‚ÄÑ‚ÄÑ‚ÄÑ‚ÄÑ 2EPFL, ruediger.urbanke@epfl.ch The work of A.¬†Montanari was partially supported by the European Union under the project EVERGROW. (February 12, 2007)
Abstract

These are the notes for a set of lectures delivered by the two authors at the Les Houches Summer School on ‚ÄòComplex Systems‚Äô in July 2006. They provide an introduction to the basic concepts in modern (probabilistic) coding theory, highlighting connections with statistical mechanics. We also stress common concepts with other disciplines dealing with similar problems that can be generically referred to as ‚Äòlarge graphical models‚Äô.

While most of the lectures are devoted to the classical channel coding problem over simple memoryless channels, we present a discussion of more complex channel models. We conclude with an overview of the main open challenges in the field.

1 Introduction and Outline

The last few years have witnessed an impressive convergence of interests between disciplines which are a priori well separated: coding and information theory, statistical inference, statistical mechanics (in particular, mean field disordered systems), as well as theoretical computer science. The underlying reason for this convergence is the importance of probabilistic models and/or probabilistic techniques in each of these domains. This has long been obvious in information theory [53], statistical mechanics [10], and statistical inference [45]. In the last few years it has also become apparent in coding theory and theoretical computer science. In the first case, the invention of Turbo codes [7] and the re-invention of Low-Density Parity-Check (LDPC) codes [30, 28] has motivated the use of random constructions for coding information in robust/compact ways [50]. In the second case (theoretical computer science) the relevance of randomized algorithms has steadily increased (see for instance [41]), thus motivating deep theoretical developments. A particularly important example is provided by the Monte Carlo Markov Chain method for counting and sampling random structures.

Given this common probabilistic background, some analogies between these disciplines is not very surprising nor is it particularly interesting. The key new ingredient which lifts the connections beyond some superficial commonalities is that one can name specific problems, questions, and results which lie at the intersection of these fields while being of central interest for each of them. The set of problems and techniques thus defined can be somewhat loosely named ‚Äútheory of large graphical models.‚Äù The typical setting is the following: a large set of random variables taking values in a finite (typically quite small) alphabet with a ‚Äúlocal‚Äù dependency structure; this local dependency structure is conveniently described by an appropriate graph.

In this lecture we shall use ‚Äúmodern‚Äù coding theory as an entry point to the domain. There are several motivations for this: (i)ùëñ(i) theoretical work on this topic is strongly motivated by concrete and well-defined practical applications; (i‚Äãi)ùëñùëñ(ii) the probabilistic approach mentioned above has been quite successful and has substantially changed the field (whence the reference to modern coding theory); (i‚Äãi‚Äãi)ùëñùëñùëñ(iii) a sufficiently detailed picture exists illustrating the interplay among different view points.

We start in Section¬†2 with a brief outline of the (channel coding) problem. This allows us to introduce the standard definitions and terminology used in this field. In Section¬†3 we introduce ensembles of codes defined by sparse random graphs and discuss their most basic property ‚Äì the weight distribution. In Section¬†4 we phrase the decoding problem as an inference problem on a graph and consider the performance of the efficient (albeit in general suboptimal) message-passing decoder. We show how the performance of such a combination (sparse graph code and message-passing decoding) can be analyzed and we discuss the relationship of the performance under message-passing decoding to the performance of the optimal decoder. In Section¬†5 we briefly touch on some problems beyond coding, in order to show as similar concept emerge there. In particular, we discuss how message passing techniques can be successfully used in some families of counting/inference problems. In Section¬†6 we show that several of the simplifying assumptions (binary case, symmetry of channel, memoryless channels) are convenient in that they allow for a simple theory but are not really necessary. In particular, we discuss a simple channel with memory and we see how to proceed in the asymmetric case. Finally, we conclude in Section¬†7 with a few fundamental open problems.

To readers who would like to find current contributions on this topic we recommend the IEEE Transactions on Information Theory. A considerably more in-depth discussion can be found in the two upcoming books Information, Physics and Computation [36] and Modern Coding Theory [50]. Standard references on coding theory are [6, 9, 26] and very readable introductions to information theory can be found in [12, 20]. Other useful reference sources are the book by Nishimori [44] as well as the book by MacKay [29].

2 Background: The Channel Coding Problem

The central problem of communications is how to transmit information reliably through a noisy (and thus unreliable) communication channel. Coding theory aims at accomplishing this task by adding a properly designed redundancy to the transmitted message. This redundancy is then used at the receiver to reconstruct the original message despite the noise introduced by the channel.

2.1 The Problem

In order to model the situation described above we shall assume that the noise is random with some known distribution.111It is worth mentioning that an alternative approach would be to consider the noise as ‚Äòadversarial‚Äô (or worst case) under some constraint on its intensity. To keep things simple we shall assume that the communication channel admits as input binary symbols x‚àà{ùü∂,ùü∑}ùë•01x\in\{{\tt 0},{\tt 1}\}, while the output belongs to some finite alphabet ùíúùíú{\cal A}. We denote the probability of observing the output y‚ààùíúùë¶ùíúy\in{\cal A} given that the input was x‚àà{ùü∂,ùü∑}ùë•01x\in\{{\tt 0},{\tt 1}\} by Q‚Äã(y|x)ùëÑconditionalùë¶ùë•Q(y|x). The channel model is defined by the transition probability matrix

Q={Q(y|x):x‚àà{ùü∂,ùü∑},y‚ààùíú}.\displaystyle Q=\{Q(y|x):\,x\in\{{\tt 0},{\tt 1}\},\;y\in{\cal A}\}\,. (2.1)

Of course, the entries of this matrix must be non-negative and normalized in such a way that ‚àëyQ‚Äã(y|x)=1subscriptùë¶ùëÑconditionalùë¶ùë•1\sum_{y}Q(y|x)=1.

It is convenient to have a few simple examples in mind. We refer to Fig.¬†1 for an illustration of the channel models which we introduce in the following three examples.

  • Example 1: The binary symmetric channel BSC‚Äã(p)BSCùëù{\rm BSC}(p) is defined by letting ùíú={ùü∂,ùü∑}ùíú01{\cal A}=\{{\tt 0},{\tt 1}\} and Q‚Äã(ùü∂|ùü∂)=Q‚Äã(ùü∑|ùü∑)=1‚àípùëÑconditional00ùëÑconditional111ùëùQ({\tt 0}|{\tt 0})=Q({\tt 1}|{\tt 1})=1-p; the normalization then enforces Q‚Äã(ùü∑|ùü∂)=Q‚Äã(ùü∂|ùü∑)=pùëÑconditional10ùëÑconditional01ùëùQ({\tt 1}|{\tt 0})=Q({\tt 0}|{\tt 1})=p. In words, the channel ‚Äúflips‚Äù the input bit with probability p‚àà[0,1]ùëù01p\in[0,1]. Since flips are introduced for each bit independently we say that the channel is memoryless. Except for an example in Section¬†6.2 all channels which we consider are memoryless.

  • Example 2: The binary erasure channel BEC‚Äã(œµ)BECitalic-œµ{\rm BEC}(\epsilon) is defined by ùíú={ùü∂,ùü∑,‚àó}ùíú01‚àó{\cal A}=\{{\tt 0},{\tt 1},\ast\} and Q‚Äã(ùü∂|ùü∂)=Q‚Äã(ùü∑|ùü∑)=1‚àíœµùëÑconditional00ùëÑconditional111italic-œµQ({\tt 0}|{\tt 0})=Q({\tt 1}|{\tt 1})=1-\epsilon while Q(‚àó|ùü∂)=Q(‚àó|ùü∑)=œµQ(\ast|{\tt 0})=Q(\ast|{\tt 1})=\epsilon. In words, the channel input is erased with probability œµitalic-œµ\epsilon and it is transmitted correctly otherwise.

  • Example 3: The Z-channel ZC(p)ùëù(p) has an output alphabet ùíú={ùü∂,ùü∑}ùíú01{\cal A}=\{{\tt 0},{\tt 1}\} but acts differently on input ùü∂0{\tt 0} (that is transmitted correctly) and ùü∑1{\tt 1} (that is flipped with probability pùëùp). We invite the reader to write the transition probability matrix.

Since in each case the input is binary we speak of a binary-input channel. Since further in all models each input symbol is distorted independently from all other ones we say that the channels are memoryless. It is convenient to further restrict our attention to symmetric channels: this means that there is an involution on ùíúùíú{\cal A} (i.e. a mapping Œπ:ùíú‚Üíùíú:ùúÑ‚Üíùíúùíú\iota:{\cal A}\to{\cal A} such that Œπ‚àòŒπ=1ùúÑùúÑ1\iota\circ\iota=1) so that Q‚Äã(y|ùü∂)=Q‚Äã(Œπ‚Äã(y)|ùü∑)ùëÑconditionalùë¶0ùëÑconditionalùúÑùë¶1Q(y|{\tt 0})=Q(\iota(y)|{\tt 1}). (E.g., if ùíú=‚Ñùùíú‚Ñù{\cal A}={\mathbb{R}} then we could require that Q‚Äã(y|ùü∂)=Q‚Äã(‚àíy|ùü∑)ùëÑconditionalùë¶0ùëÑconditionalùë¶1Q(y|{\tt 0})=Q(-y|{\tt 1}).) This condition is satisfied by the first two examples above but not by the third one. To summarize these three properties one refers to such models as BMS channels.

In order to complete the problem description we need to formalize the information which is to be transmitted. We shall model this probabilistically as well and assume that the transmitter has an information source that provides an infinite stream of i.i.d. fair coins: {zi;i=0,1,2,‚Ä¶}formulae-sequencesubscriptùëßùëñùëñ012‚Ä¶\{z_{i};i=0,1,2,\dots\}, with zi‚àà{ùü∂,ùü∑}subscriptùëßùëñ01z_{i}\in\{{\tt 0},{\tt 1}\} uniformly at random. The goal is to reproduce this stream faithfully after communicating it over the noisy channel.

Let us stress that, despite its simplification, the present setting contains most of the crucial and challenges of the channel coding problem. Some of the many generalizations are described in Section¬†6.

2.2 Block Coding

The (general) coding strategy we shall consider here is block coding. It works as follows:

  • ‚Ä¢

    The source stream {zi}subscriptùëßùëñ\{z_{i}\} is chopped into blocks of length LùêøL. Denote one such block by z¬Ø¬Øùëß\underline{z}, z¬Ø=(z1,‚Ä¶,zL)‚àà{ùü∂,ùü∑}L¬Øùëßsubscriptùëß1‚Ä¶subscriptùëßùêøsuperscript01ùêø\underline{z}=(z_{1},\dots,z_{L})\in\{{\tt 0},{\tt 1}\}^{L}.

  • ‚Ä¢

    Each block is fed into an encoder. This is a map ùñ•:{ùü∂,ùü∑}L‚Üí{ùü∂,ùü∑}N:ùñ•‚Üísuperscript01ùêøsuperscript01ùëÅ{\sf F}:\{{\tt 0},{\tt 1}\}^{L}\to\{{\tt 0},{\tt 1}\}^{N}, for some fixed N>LùëÅùêøN>L (the blocklength). In words, the encoder introduces redundancy in the source message. Without loss of generality we can assume ùñ•ùñ•{\sf F} to be injective. It this was not the case, even in the absence of noise, we could not uniquely recover the transmitted information from the observed codeword.

  • ‚Ä¢

    The image of {ùü∂,ùü∑}Lsuperscript01ùêø\{{\tt 0},{\tt 1}\}^{L} under the map ùñ•ùñ•{\sf F} is called the codebook, or sometimes the code, and it will be denoted by ‚Ñ≠‚Ñ≠{\mathfrak{C}}. The code contains |‚Ñ≠|=2L‚Ñ≠superscript2ùêø|{\mathfrak{C}}|=2^{L} strings of length NùëÅN called codewords. These are the possible channel inputs. The codeword x¬Ø=ùñ•‚Äã(z¬Ø)¬Øùë•ùñ•¬Øùëß\underline{x}={\sf F}(\underline{z}) is sent through the channel, bit by bit.

  • ‚Ä¢

    Let y¬Ø=(y1,‚ãØ,yN)‚ààùíúN¬Øùë¶subscriptùë¶1‚ãØsubscriptùë¶ùëÅsuperscriptùíúùëÅ\underline{y}=(y_{1},\cdots,y_{N})\in{\cal A}^{N} be the channel output. Conditioned on x¬Ø¬Øùë•\underline{x} the yisubscriptùë¶ùëñy_{i}, i=1,‚ãØ,Lùëñ1‚ãØùêøi=1,\cdots,L, are independent random variables with distribution yi=dQ(‚ãÖ|xi)y_{i}\stackrel{{\scriptstyle{\rm d}}}{{=}}Q(\cdot\,|x_{i}) (here and below =dsuperscriptd\stackrel{{\scriptstyle{\rm d}}}{{=}} denotes identity in distribution and x=dP‚Äã(‚ãÖ)superscriptdùë•ùëÉ‚ãÖx\stackrel{{\scriptstyle{\rm d}}}{{=}}P(\,\cdot\,) means that xùë•x is a random variable with distribution P‚Äã(‚ãÖ)ùëÉ‚ãÖP(\,\cdot\,)).

  • ‚Ä¢

    The channel output is fed into a decoder, which is a map ùñ•^:ùíúN‚Üí{ùü∂,ùü∑}L:^ùñ•‚ÜísuperscriptùíúùëÅsuperscript01ùêø\widehat{\sf F}:{\cal A}^{N}\to\{{\tt 0},{\tt 1}\}^{L}. It is the objective of the decoder to reconstruct the source z¬Ø¬Øùëß\underline{z} from the noisy channel output y¬Ø¬Øùë¶\underline{y}.

The flow chart describing this coding scheme is shown in Fig.¬†2. It is convenient to slightly modify the above scheme. Notice that, under the hypothesis that the encoder is injective, the codebook is in one-to-one correspondence with the source sequences. Since these are equiprobable, the transmitted codewords are equiprobable as well. We can therefore equivalently assume that the transmitter picks a codeword uniformly at random and transmits it. Every reference to the source stream can be eliminated if we redefine the decoder to be a map ùñ•^:ùíúN‚Üí{ùü∂,ùü∑}N:^ùñ•‚ÜísuperscriptùíúùëÅsuperscript01ùëÅ\widehat{\sf F}:{\cal A}^{N}\to\{{\tt 0},{\tt 1}\}^{N}, i.e., the decoder aims to reconstruct the transmitted codeword. If ùñ•^‚Äã(y¬Ø)‚àâ‚Ñ≠^ùñ•¬Øùë¶‚Ñ≠\widehat{\sf F}(\underline{y})\not\in{\mathfrak{C}} we declare an error.222More precisely, if we are interested only in the block probability of error, i.e., the frequency at which the whole block of data is decoded correctly, then indeed any one-to-one mapping between information word and codeword performs identical. If, on the other hand, we are interested in the fraction of bits that we decode correctly then the exact mapping from information word to codeword does come into play. We shall ignore this somewhat subtle point in the sequel. In the following we shall also use the notation ùñ•^‚Äã(y¬Ø)=x¬Ø^‚Äã(y¬Ø)=(x^1‚Äã(y¬Ø),‚Ä¶,x^N‚Äã(y¬Ø))^ùñ•¬Øùë¶^¬Øùë•¬Øùë¶subscript^ùë•1¬Øùë¶‚Ä¶subscript^ùë•ùëÅ¬Øùë¶\widehat{\sf F}(\underline{y})=\widehat{\underline{x}}(\underline{y})=(\widehat{x}_{1}(\underline{y}),\dots,\widehat{x}_{N}(\underline{y})).

One crucial parameter of a code is its rate: it quantifies how many bits of information are transmitted per channel use,

R‚â°LN=1N‚Äãlog2‚Å°|‚Ñ≠|.ùëÖùêøùëÅ1ùëÅsubscript2‚Ñ≠\displaystyle R\equiv\frac{L}{N}=\frac{1}{N}\,\log_{2}|{\mathfrak{C}}|\,. (2.2)

Two fundamental performance parameters are the bit (or ‚Äòsymbol‚Äô) and block (or ‚Äòword‚Äô) error rates. The block error rate is the probability that the input codeword is not recovered correctly at the end of the process,

PB‚â°‚Ñô‚Äã{x¬Ø^‚Äã(y¬Ø)‚â†x¬Ø}.subscriptPB‚Ñô^¬Øùë•¬Øùë¶¬Øùë•\displaystyle{\rm P}_{{\rm B}}\equiv{\mathbb{P}}\left\{\widehat{\underline{x}}(\underline{y})\neq\underline{x}\right\}\,. (2.3)

The bit error rate is the expected fraction of bits that are not recovered correctly,

Pb‚â°1N‚Äã‚àëi=1N‚Ñô‚Äã{x^i‚Äã(y¬Ø)‚â†xi}.subscriptPb1ùëÅsuperscriptsubscriptùëñ1ùëÅ‚Ñôsubscript^ùë•ùëñ¬Øùë¶subscriptùë•ùëñ\displaystyle{\rm P}_{{\rm b}}\equiv\frac{1}{N}\sum_{i=1}^{N}{\mathbb{P}}\left\{\widehat{x}_{i}(\underline{y})\neq x_{i}\right\}\,. (2.4)

It should not be too surprising that one can trade-off rate and error probability. We want to achieve a high rate and achieve a low probability of error. However, increasing the rate decreases the redundancy built into the codeword, thus inducing a higher error probability. The aim of coding theory is to choose the code ‚Ñ≠‚Ñ≠{\mathfrak{C}} and the decoding function x¬Ø^‚Äã(‚ãÖ)^¬Øùë•‚ãÖ\widehat{\underline{x}}(\,\cdot\,) in a way to optimize this trade-off.

2.3 Decoding

Given the code there is a simple (although in general not computationally efficient) prescription for the decoder. If we want to minimize the block error rate, we must chose the most likely codeword,

x¬Ø^B‚Äã(y¬Ø)‚â°arg‚Å°maxx¬Ø‚Å°‚Ñô‚Äã{X¬Ø=x¬Ø|Y¬Ø=y¬Ø}.superscript^¬Øùë•B¬Øùë¶subscript¬Øùë•‚Ñôconditional-set¬Øùëã¬Øùë•¬Øùëå¬Øùë¶\displaystyle\widehat{\underline{x}}^{\mbox{\tiny{B}}}(\underline{y})\equiv\arg\max_{\underline{x}}{\mathbb{P}}\{\underline{X}=\underline{x}|\underline{Y}=\underline{y}\}\,. (2.5)

To minimize the bit error rate we must instead return the sequence of most likely bits,

x^ib‚Äã(y¬Ø)‚â°arg‚Å°maxxi‚Å°‚Ñô‚Äã{Xi=xi|Y¬Ø=y¬Ø}.superscriptsubscript^ùë•ùëñb¬Øùë¶subscriptsubscriptùë•ùëñ‚Ñôconditional-setsubscriptùëãùëñsubscriptùë•ùëñ¬Øùëå¬Øùë¶\displaystyle\widehat{x}_{i}^{\mbox{\tiny{b}}}(\underline{y})\equiv\arg\max_{x_{i}}{\mathbb{P}}\{X_{i}=x_{i}|\underline{Y}=\underline{y}\}\,. (2.6)

The reason of these prescriptions is the object of the next exercise.

(2.12)

The word MAP and bit MAP rule can then be written as

x¬Ø^B‚Äã(y¬Ø)superscript^¬Øùë•B¬Øùë¶\displaystyle\widehat{\underline{x}}^{\mbox{\tiny{B}}}(\underline{y}) =\displaystyle= arg‚Å°minx¬Ø‚Å°E‚Ñ≠,y‚Äã(x¬Ø),subscript¬Øùë•subscriptùê∏‚Ñ≠ùë¶¬Øùë•\displaystyle\arg\min_{\underline{x}}E_{{\mathfrak{C}},y}(\underline{x})\,, (2.13)
x^ib‚Äã(y¬Ø)superscriptsubscript^ùë•ùëñb¬Øùë¶\displaystyle\widehat{x}_{i}^{\mbox{\tiny{b}}}(\underline{y}) =\displaystyle= arg‚Å°maxxi‚Äã‚àëxj:j‚â†iŒº‚Ñ≠,y‚Äã(x¬Ø).subscriptsubscriptùë•ùëñsubscript:subscriptùë•ùëóùëóùëñsubscriptùúá‚Ñ≠ùë¶¬Øùë•\displaystyle\arg\max_{x_{i}}\sum_{x_{j}:j\neq i}\mu_{{\mathfrak{C}},y}(\underline{x})\,. (2.14)

In words, word MAP amounts to computing the ground state of a certain energy function, and bit MAP corresponds to computing the expectation with respect to the Boltzmann distribution. Notice furthermore that Œº‚Äã(‚ãÖ)ùúá‚ãÖ\mu(\,\cdot\,) is itself random because of the randomness in yùë¶y (and we shall introduce further randomness in the choice of the code). This is analogous to what happens in statistical physics of disordered systems, with y¬Ø¬Øùë¶\underline{y} playing the role of quenched random variables.

2.4 Conditional Entropy and Free Energy

As mentioned above, we are interested in understanding the properties of the (random) distribution Œº‚Ñ≠,y‚Äã(‚ãÖ)subscriptùúá‚Ñ≠ùë¶‚ãÖ\mu_{{\mathfrak{C}},y}(\,\cdot\,). One possible way of formalizing this idea is to consider the entropy of this distribution.

Let us recall that the (Shannon) entropy of a discrete random variable XùëãX (or, equivalently, of its distribution) quantifies, in a very precise sense, the ‚Äòuncertainty‚Äô associated with XùëãX.444For a very readable account of information theory we recommend [12]. It is given by

H‚Äã(X)=‚àí‚àëx‚Ñô‚Äã(x)‚Äãlog‚Å°‚Ñô‚Äã(x).ùêªùëãsubscriptùë•‚Ñôùë•‚Ñôùë•\displaystyle H(X)=-\sum_{x}{\mathbb{P}}(x)\log{\mathbb{P}}(x)\,. (2.15)

For two random variables XùëãX and YùëåY one defines the conditional entropy of XùëãX given YùëåY as

H‚Äã(X|Y)ùêªconditionalùëãùëå\displaystyle H(X|Y) =\displaystyle= ‚àí‚àëx,y‚Ñô‚Äã(x,y)‚Äãlog‚Å°‚Ñô‚Äã(x|y)=ùîºy‚Äã{‚àí‚àëx‚Ñô‚Äã(x|Y)‚Äãlog‚Å°‚Ñô‚Äã(x|Y)}.subscriptùë•ùë¶‚Ñôùë•ùë¶‚Ñôconditionalùë•ùë¶subscriptùîºùë¶subscriptùë•‚Ñôconditionalùë•ùëå‚Ñôconditionalùë•ùëå\displaystyle-\sum_{x,y}{\mathbb{P}}(x,y)\log{\mathbb{P}}(x|y)={\mathbb{E}}_{y}\left\{-\sum_{x}{\mathbb{P}}(x|Y)\log{\mathbb{P}}(x|Y)\right\}\,. (2.16)

This quantifies the remaining uncertainty about XùëãX when YùëåY is observed.

Considering now the coding problem. Denote by X¬Ø¬Øùëã\underline{X} the (uniformly random) transmitted codeword and by Y¬Ø¬Øùëå\underline{Y} the channel output. The right-most expression in Eq.¬†(2.16) states that H‚Äã(X¬Ø|Y¬Ø)ùêªconditional¬Øùëã¬ØùëåH(\underline{X}|\underline{Y}) is the expectation of the entropy of the conditional distribution Œº‚Ñ≠,y‚Äã(‚ãÖ)subscriptùúá‚Ñ≠ùë¶‚ãÖ\mu_{{\mathfrak{C}},y}(\,\cdot\,) with respect to y¬Ø¬Øùë¶\underline{y}.

Let us denote by ŒΩ‚Ñ≠‚Äã(x)subscriptùúà‚Ñ≠ùë•\nu_{{\mathfrak{C}}}(x) the probability that a uniformly random codeword in ‚Ñ≠‚Ñ≠{\mathfrak{C}} takes the value xùë•x at the iùëñi-th position, averaged over iùëñi. Then a straightforward calculation yields

H‚Äã(X¬Ø|Y¬Ø)ùêªconditional¬Øùëã¬Øùëå\displaystyle H(\underline{X}|\underline{Y}) =\displaystyle= ‚àí1|‚Ñ≠|‚Äã‚àëx¬Ø,y¬Ø‚àèi=1NQ‚Äã(yi|xi)‚Äãlog‚Å°{1Z‚Äã(‚Ñ≠,y¬Ø)‚Äã‚àèi=1NQ‚Äã(yi|xi)},1‚Ñ≠subscript¬Øùë•¬Øùë¶superscriptsubscriptproductùëñ1ùëÅùëÑconditionalsubscriptùë¶ùëñsubscriptùë•ùëñ1ùëç‚Ñ≠¬Øùë¶superscriptsubscriptproductùëñ1ùëÅùëÑconditionalsubscriptùë¶ùëñsubscriptùë•ùëñ\displaystyle-\frac{1}{|{\mathfrak{C}}|}\sum_{\underline{x},\underline{y}}\prod_{i=1}^{N}Q(y_{i}|x_{i})\,\log\left\{\frac{1}{Z({\mathfrak{C}},\underline{y})}\prod_{i=1}^{N}Q(y_{i}|x_{i})\right\}\,, (2.17)
=\displaystyle= ‚àíN‚Äã‚àëx,yŒΩ‚Ñ≠‚Äã(x)‚ÄãQ‚Äã(y|x)‚Äãlog‚Å°Q‚Äã(y|x)+ùîºy¬Ø‚Äãlog‚Å°Z‚Äã(‚Ñ≠,y¬Ø).ùëÅsubscriptùë•ùë¶subscriptùúà‚Ñ≠ùë•ùëÑconditionalùë¶ùë•ùëÑconditionalùë¶ùë•subscriptùîº¬Øùë¶ùëç‚Ñ≠¬Øùë¶\displaystyle-N\sum_{x,y}\nu_{{\mathfrak{C}}}(x)Q(y|x)\log Q(y|x)+{\mathbb{E}}_{\underline{y}}\log Z({\mathfrak{C}},\underline{y})\,. (2.18)

The ‚Äòtype‚Äô ŒΩ‚Ñ≠‚Äã(x)subscriptùúà‚Ñ≠ùë•\nu_{{\mathfrak{C}}}(x) is usually a fairly straightforward characteristic of the code. For most of the examples considered below we can take ŒΩ‚Ñ≠‚Äã(ùü∂)=ŒΩ‚Ñ≠‚Äã(ùü∑)=1/2subscriptùúà‚Ñ≠0subscriptùúà‚Ñ≠112\nu_{{\mathfrak{C}}}({\tt 0})=\nu_{{\mathfrak{C}}}({\tt 1})=1/2. As a consequence the first of the terms above is trivial to compute (it requires summing over 2‚Äã|ùíú|2ùíú2|{\cal A}| terms).

On the other hand the second term is highly non-trivial. The reader will recognize the expectation of a free energy, with y¬Ø¬Øùë¶\underline{y} playing the role of a quenched random variable.

The conditional entropy H‚Äã(X¬Ø|Y¬Ø)ùêªconditional¬Øùëã¬ØùëåH(\underline{X}|\underline{Y}) provides an answer to the question: how many codewords is Œº‚Ñ≠,y‚Äã(‚ãÖ)subscriptùúá‚Ñ≠ùë¶‚ãÖ\mu_{{\mathfrak{C}},y}(\,\cdot\,) spread over? It turns out that about eH‚Äã(X¬Ø|Y¬Ø)superscriptùëíùêªconditional¬Øùëã¬Øùëåe^{H(\underline{X}|\underline{Y})} of them carry most of the weight.

2.5 Shannon Theorem and Random Coding

As mentioned above, there exists an obvious tradeoff between high rate and low error probability. In his celebrated 1948 paper [53], Shannon derived the optimal error probability-vs-rate curve in the limit of large blocklengths. In particular, he proved that if the rate is larger than a particular threshold, then the error probability can be made arbitrarily small. The threshold depends on the channel and it is called the channel capacity. The capacity of a BMS channel (measured in bits per channel use) is given by the following elementary expression,

ùô≤‚Äã(Q)=ùô≤ùëÑabsent\displaystyle{\tt C}(Q)= H‚Äã(X)‚àíH‚Äã(X|Y)ùêªùëãùêªconditionalùëãùëå\displaystyle H(X)-H(X|Y)
=\displaystyle= 1+‚àëyQ‚Äã(y|ùü∂)‚Äãlog2‚Å°{Q‚Äã(y|ùü∂)Q‚Äã(y|ùü∂)+Q‚Äã(y|ùü∑)}.1subscriptùë¶ùëÑconditionalùë¶0subscript2ùëÑconditionalùë¶0ùëÑconditionalùë¶0ùëÑconditionalùë¶1\displaystyle 1+\sum_{y}Q(y|{\tt 0})\log_{2}\left\{\frac{Q(y|{\tt 0})}{Q(y|{\tt 0})+Q(y|{\tt 1})}\right\}\,.

For instance, the capacity of a BSC‚Äã(p)BSCùëù{\rm BSC}(p) is ùô≤‚Äã(p)=1‚àíùî•2‚Äã(p)ùô≤ùëù1subscriptùî•2ùëù{\tt C}(p)=1-{\mathfrak{h}}_{2}(p), (where ùî•2‚Äã(p)=‚àíp‚Äãlog2‚Å°p‚àí(1‚àíp)‚Äãlog2‚Å°(1‚àíp)subscriptùî•2ùëùùëùsubscript2ùëù1ùëùsubscript21ùëù{\mathfrak{h}}_{2}(p)=-p\log_{2}p-(1-p)\log_{2}(1-p) is the entropy of a Bernoulli random variable of parameter pùëùp) while the capacity of a BEC‚Äã(œµ)BECitalic-œµ{\rm BEC}(\epsilon) is ùô≤‚Äã(œµ)=1‚àíœµùô≤italic-œµ1italic-œµ{\tt C}(\epsilon)=1-\epsilon. As an illustration, the capacity of a BSC‚Äã(p)BSCùëù{\rm BSC}(p) with flip probability p‚âà0.110028ùëù0.110028p\approx 0.110028 is ùô≤‚Äã(p)=1/2ùô≤ùëù12{\tt C}(p)=1/2: such a channel can be used to transmit reliably 1/2121/2 bit of information per channel use.

Theorem 2.1 (Channel Coding Theorem).

For any BMS channel with transition probability QùëÑQ and R<ùô≤‚Äã(Q)ùëÖùô≤ùëÑR<{\tt C}(Q) there exists a sequence of codes ‚Ñ≠Nsubscript‚Ñ≠ùëÅ{\mathfrak{C}}_{N} of increasing blocklength NùëÅN and rate RN‚ÜíR‚ÜísubscriptùëÖùëÅùëÖR_{N}\to R whose block error probability PB(N)‚Üí0‚ÜísuperscriptsubscriptPBùëÅ0{\rm P}_{{\rm B}}^{(N)}\to 0 as N‚Üí‚àû‚ÜíùëÅN\to\infty.

Vice versa, for any R>ùô≤‚Äã(Q)ùëÖùô≤ùëÑR>{\tt C}(Q) the block error probability of a code with rate at least RùëÖR is bounded away from 00.

The prove of the first part (‚Äòachievability‚Äô) is one of the first examples of the so-called ‚Äòprobabilistic method‚Äô. In order to prove that there exists an object with a certain property (a code with small error probability), one constructs a probability distribution over all potential candidates (all codes of a certain blocklength and rate) and shows that a random element has the desired property with non-vanishing probability. The power of this approach is in the (meta-mathematical) observation that random constructions are often much easier to produce than explicit, deterministic ones.

The distribution over codes proposed by Shannon is usually referred to as the random code (or, Shannon) ensemble, and is particularly simple. One picks a code ‚Ñ≠‚Ñ≠{\mathfrak{C}} uniformly at random among all codes of blocklength NùëÅN and rate RùëÖR. More explicitly, one picks 2N‚ÄãRsuperscript2ùëÅùëÖ2^{NR} codewords as uniformly random points in the hypercube {ùü∂,ùü∑}Nsuperscript01ùëÅ\{{\tt 0},{\tt 1}\}^{N}. This means that each codeword is a string of NùëÅN fair coins x¬Ø(Œ±)=(x1(Œ±),‚Ä¶,xN(Œ±))superscript¬Øùë•ùõºsubscriptsuperscriptùë•ùõº1‚Ä¶subscriptsuperscriptùë•ùõºùëÅ\underline{x}^{(\alpha)}=(x^{(\alpha)}_{1},\dots,x^{(\alpha)}_{N}) for555The reader might notice two imprecisions with this definition. First, 2N‚ÄãRsuperscript2ùëÅùëÖ2^{NR} is not necessarily an integer: one should rather use ‚åà2N‚ÄãR‚åâsuperscript2ùëÅùëÖ\lceil 2^{NR}\rceil codewords, but the difference is obviously negligible. Second, in contradiction with our definition, two codewords may coincide if they are independent. Again, only an exponentially small fraction of codewords will coincide and they can be neglected for all practical purposes. Œ±=1,‚Ä¶,2N‚ÄãRùõº1‚Ä¶superscript2ùëÅùëÖ\alpha=1,\dots,2^{NR}.

Once the ensemble is defined, one can estimate its average block error probability and show that it vanishes in the blocklength for R<ùô≤‚Äã(Q)ùëÖùô≤ùëÑR<{\tt C}(Q). Here we will limit ourselves to providing some basic ‚Äògeometric‚Äô intuition of why a random code from the Shannon ensemble performs well with high probability.666Here and in the rest of the lectures, the expression with high probability means ‚Äòwith probability approaching one as N‚Üí‚àû‚ÜíùëÅN\to\infty‚Äô

Let us consider a particular codeword, say x¬Ø(0)superscript¬Øùë•0\underline{x}^{(0)}, and try to estimate the distance (from x¬Ø(0)superscript¬Øùë•0\underline{x}^{(0)}) at which other codewords in ‚Ñ≠‚Ñ≠{\mathfrak{C}} can be found. This information is conveyed by the distance enumerator

ùí©x¬Ø(0)‚Äã(d)‚â°#‚Äã{x¬Ø‚àà‚Ñ≠\x¬Ø(0)‚Äã¬†such that¬†‚Äãd‚Äã(x¬Ø,x¬Ø(0))=d},subscriptùí©superscript¬Øùë•0ùëë#¬Øùë•\‚Ñ≠superscript¬Øùë•0¬†such that¬†ùëë¬Øùë•superscript¬Øùë•0ùëë\displaystyle{\cal N}_{\underline{x}^{(0)}}(d)\equiv\#\left\{\;\underline{x}\in{\mathfrak{C}}\backslash\underline{x}^{(0)}\;\mbox{ such that }\;d(\underline{x},\underline{x}^{(0)})=d\;\right\}\,, (2.19)

where d‚Äã(x¬Ø,x¬Ø‚Ä≤)ùëë¬Øùë•superscript¬Øùë•‚Ä≤d(\underline{x},\underline{x}^{\prime}) is the Hamming distance between x¬Ø¬Øùë•\underline{x} and x¬Ø‚Ä≤superscript¬Øùë•‚Ä≤\underline{x}^{\prime} (i.e., the number of positions in which x¬Ø¬Øùë•\underline{x} and x¬Ø‚Ä≤superscript¬Øùë•‚Ä≤\underline{x}^{\prime} differ). The expectation of this quantity is the number of codewords different from x¬Ø(0)superscript¬Øùë•0\underline{x}^{(0)} (that is (2N‚ÄãR‚àí1)superscript2ùëÅùëÖ1(2^{NR}-1)) times the probability that any given codeword has distance dùëëd from x¬Ø(0)superscript¬Øùë•0\underline{x}^{(0)}. Since each entry is independent and different with probability 1/2121/2, we get

ùîº‚Äãùí©x¬Ø(0)‚Äã(d)=(2N‚ÄãR‚àí1)‚Äã12N‚Äã(Nd)‚âê2N‚Äã[R‚àí1+ùî•2‚Äã(Œ¥)],ùîºsubscriptùí©superscript¬Øùë•0ùëësuperscript2ùëÅùëÖ11superscript2ùëÅbinomialùëÅùëëapproaches-limitsuperscript2ùëÅdelimited-[]ùëÖ1subscriptùî•2ùõø\displaystyle{\mathbb{E}}\,{\cal N}_{\underline{x}^{(0)}}(d)=(2^{NR}-1)\,\;\frac{1}{2^{N}}\binom{N}{d}\doteq 2^{N[R-1+{\mathfrak{h}}_{2}(\delta)]}\,, (2.20)

where Œ¥=d/NùõøùëëùëÅ\delta=d/N and ‚âêapproaches-limit\doteq denotes equality to the leading exponential order.777Explicitly, we write fN‚âêgNapproaches-limitsubscriptùëìùëÅsubscriptùëîùëÅf_{N}\doteq g_{N} if 1N‚Äãlog‚Å°fN/gN‚Üí0‚Üí1ùëÅsubscriptùëìùëÅsubscriptùëîùëÅ0\frac{1}{N}\log f_{N}/g_{N}\to 0.

The exponent R‚àí1+ùî•2‚Äã(Œ¥)ùëÖ1subscriptùî•2ùõøR-1+{\mathfrak{h}}_{2}(\delta) is plotted in Fig.¬†3. For Œ¥ùõø\delta sufficiently small (and R<1ùëÖ1R<1) this exponent is negative. Its first zero, to be denoted as Œ¥GV‚Äã(R)subscriptùõøGVùëÖ\delta_{\rm GV}(R), is called the Gilbert-Varshamov distance. For any Œ¥<Œ¥GV‚Äã(R)ùõøsubscriptùõøGVùëÖ\delta<\delta_{\rm GV}(R) the expected number of codewords of distance at most N‚ÄãŒ¥ùëÅùõøN\delta from x¬Ø(0)superscript¬Øùë•0\underline{x}^{(0)} is exponentially small in NùëÅN. It follows that the probability to find any codeword at distance smaller than N‚ÄãŒ¥ùëÅùõøN\delta is exponentially small in NùëÅN.

Vice-versa, for d=N‚ÄãŒ¥ùëëùëÅùõød=N\delta, with Œ¥>Œ¥GV‚Äã(R)ùõøsubscriptùõøGVùëÖ\delta>\delta_{\rm GV}(R), ùîº‚Äãùí©x¬Ø(0)‚Äã(d)ùîºsubscriptùí©superscript¬Øùë•0ùëë{\mathbb{E}}\,{\cal N}_{\underline{x}^{(0)}}(d) is exponentially large in NùëÅN. Indeed, ùí©x¬Ø(0)‚Äã(d)subscriptùí©superscript¬Øùë•0ùëë{\cal N}_{\underline{x}^{(0)}}(d) is a binomial random variable, because each of the 2N‚ÄãR‚àí1superscript2ùëÅùëÖ12^{NR}-1 codewords is at distance dùëëd independently and with the same probability. As a consequence, ùí©x¬Ø(0)‚Äã(d)subscriptùí©superscript¬Øùë•0ùëë{\cal N}_{\underline{x}^{(0)}}(d) is exponentially large as well with high probability.

The bottom line of this discussion is that, for any given codeword x¬Ø(0)superscript¬Øùë•0\underline{x}^{(0)} in ‚Ñ≠‚Ñ≠{\mathfrak{C}}, the closest other codeword is, with high probability, at distance N‚Äã(Œ¥GV‚Äã(R)¬±Œµ)ùëÅplus-or-minussubscriptùõøGVùëÖùúÄN(\delta_{\rm GV}(R)\pm\varepsilon). A sketch of this situation is provided in Fig.¬†4.

Let us assume that the codeword x¬Ø(0)superscript¬Øùë•0\underline{x}^{(0)} is transmitted through a BSC‚Äã(p)BSCùëù{\rm BSC}(p). Denote by y¬Ø‚àà{ùü∂,ùü∑}N¬Øùë¶superscript01ùëÅ\underline{y}\in\{{\tt 0},{\tt 1}\}^{N} the channel output. By the law of large numbers d‚Äã(x¬Ø,y¬Ø)‚âàN‚Äãpùëë¬Øùë•¬Øùë¶ùëÅùëùd(\underline{x},\underline{y})\approx Np with high probability. The receiver tries to reconstruct the transmitted codeword from y¬Ø¬Øùë¶\underline{y} using word MAP decoding. Using Eq.¬†(2.12), we see that the ‚Äòenergy‚Äô of a codeword x¬Ø(Œ±)superscript¬Øùë•ùõº\underline{x}^{(\alpha)} (or, in more conventional terms, its log-likelihood) is given by

E‚Äã(x¬Ø(Œ±))ùê∏superscript¬Øùë•ùõº\displaystyle E(\underline{x}^{(\alpha)}) =\displaystyle= ‚àí‚àëi=1Nlog‚Å°Q‚Äã(yi|xi)=‚àí‚àëi=1N{ùïÄ‚Äã(yi=xi(Œ±))‚Äãlog‚Å°(1‚àíp)+ùïÄ‚Äã(yi‚â†xi(Œ±))‚Äãlog‚Å°p}superscriptsubscriptùëñ1ùëÅùëÑconditionalsubscriptùë¶ùëñsubscriptùë•ùëñsuperscriptsubscriptùëñ1ùëÅùïÄsubscriptùë¶ùëñsubscriptsuperscriptùë•ùõºùëñ1ùëùùïÄsubscriptùë¶ùëñsubscriptsuperscriptùë•ùõºùëñùëù\displaystyle-\sum_{i=1}^{N}\log Q(y_{i}|x_{i})=-\sum_{i=1}^{N}\left\{{\mathbb{I}}(y_{i}=x^{(\alpha)}_{i})\log(1-p)+{\mathbb{I}}(y_{i}\neq x^{(\alpha)}_{i})\log p\right\} (2.21)
=\displaystyle= N‚ÄãA‚Äã(p)+2‚ÄãB‚Äã(p)‚Äãd‚Äã(x¬Ø(Œ±),y¬Ø),ùëÅùê¥ùëù2ùêµùëùùëësuperscript¬Øùë•ùõº¬Øùë¶\displaystyle NA(p)+2B(p)d(\underline{x}^{(\alpha)},\underline{y})\,, (2.22)

where A‚Äã(p)‚â°‚àílog‚Å°pùê¥ùëùùëùA(p)\equiv-\log p and B‚Äã(p)‚â°12‚Äãlog‚Å°(1‚àíp)/pùêµùëù121ùëùùëùB(p)\equiv\frac{1}{2}\log(1-p)/p. For p<1/2ùëù12p<1/2, B‚Äã(p)>0ùêµùëù0B(p)>0 and word MAP decoding amounts to finding the codeword x¬Ø(Œ±)superscript¬Øùë•ùõº\underline{x}^{(\alpha)} which is closest in Hamming distance to the channel output y¬Ø¬Øùë¶\underline{y}. By the triangle inequality, the distance between y¬Ø¬Øùë¶\underline{y} and any of the ‚Äòincorrect‚Äô codewords is ‚â≥N‚Äã(Œ¥GV‚Äã(R)‚àíp)greater-than-or-equivalent-toabsentùëÅsubscriptùõøGVùëÖùëù\gtrsim N(\delta_{\rm GV}(R)-p). For p<Œ¥GV‚Äã(R)/2ùëùsubscriptùõøGVùëÖ2p<\delta_{\rm GV}(R)/2 this is with high probability larger than the distance from x¬Ø(0)superscript¬Øùë•0\underline{x}^{(0)}.

The above argument implies that, for p<Œ¥GV‚Äã(R)/2ùëùsubscriptùõøGVùëÖ2p<\delta_{\rm GV}(R)/2, the expected block error rate of a random code from Shannon‚Äôs ensemble vanishes as N‚Üí‚àû‚ÜíùëÅN\to\infty. Notice that the channel coding theorem promises instead vanishing error probability whenever R<1‚àíùî•2‚Äã(p)ùëÖ1subscriptùî•2ùëùR<1-{\mathfrak{h}}_{2}(p), that is (for p<1/2ùëù12p<1/2) p<Œ¥GV‚Äã(R)ùëùsubscriptùõøGVùëÖp<\delta_{\rm GV}(R). The factor 2 of discrepancy can be recovered through a more careful argument.

Without entering into details, it is interesting to understand the basic reason for the discrepancy between the Shannon Theorem and the above argument. This is related to the geometry of high dimensional spaces. Let us assume for simplicity that the minimum distance between any two codewords in ‚Ñ≠‚Ñ≠{\mathfrak{C}} is at least N‚Äã(Œ¥GV‚Äã(R)‚àíŒµ)ùëÅsubscriptùõøGVùëÖùúÄN(\delta_{\rm GV}(R)-\varepsilon). In a given random code, this is the case for most codeword pairs. We can then eliminate the pairs that do not satisfy this constraint, thus modifying the code rate in a negligible way (this procedure is called expurgation). The resulting code will have minimum distance (the minimum distance among any two codewords in ‚Ñ≠‚Ñ≠{\mathfrak{C}}) d‚Äã(‚Ñ≠)‚âàN‚ÄãŒ¥GV‚Äã(R)ùëë‚Ñ≠ùëÅsubscriptùõøGVùëÖd({\mathfrak{C}})\approx N\delta_{\rm GV}(R).

Imagine that we use such a code to communicate through a BSC and that exactly nùëõn bits are flipped. By the triangular inequality, as long as n<d‚Äã(‚Ñ≠)/2ùëõùëë‚Ñ≠2n<d({\mathfrak{C}})/2, the word MAP decoder will recover the transmitted message for all error patterns. If on the other hand n>d‚Äã(‚Ñ≠)/2ùëõùëë‚Ñ≠2n>d({\mathfrak{C}})/2, there are error patterns involving nùëõn bits such that the word-MAP decoder does not return the transmitted codeword. If for instance there exists a single codeword x¬Ø(1)superscript¬Øùë•1\underline{x}^{(1)} at distance d‚Äã(‚Ñ≠)=2‚Äãn‚àí1ùëë‚Ñ≠2ùëõ1d({\mathfrak{C}})=2n-1 from x¬Ø(0)superscript¬Øùë•0\underline{x}^{(0)}, any pattern involving nùëõn out of the 2‚Äãn‚àí12ùëõ12n-1 such that xi(0)‚â†xi(1)superscriptsubscriptùë•ùëñ0superscriptsubscriptùë•ùëñ1x_{i}^{(0)}\neq x_{i}^{(1)}, will induce a decoding error. However, it might well be that most error patterns with the same number of errors can be corrected.

Shannon‚Äôs Theorem points out that this is indeed the case until the number of bits flipped by the channel is roughly equal to the minimum distance d‚Äã(‚Ñ≠)ùëë‚Ñ≠d({\mathfrak{C}}).

3 Sparse Graph Codes

Shannon‚Äôs Theorem provides a randomized construction to find a code with ‚Äòessentially optimal‚Äô rate vs error probability tradeoff. In practice, however, one cannot use random codes for communications. Just storing the code ‚Ñ≠‚Ñ≠{\mathfrak{C}} requires a memory which grows exponentially in the blocklength. In the same vein the optimal decoding procedure requires an exponentially increasing effort. On the other hand, we can not use very short codes since their performance is not very good. To see this assume that we transmit over the BSC with parameter pùëùp. If the blocklength is NùëÅN then the standard deviation of the number of errors contained in a block is N‚Äãp‚Äã(1‚àíp)ùëÅùëù1ùëù\sqrt{Np(1-p)}. Unless this quantity is very small compared to N‚ÄãpùëÅùëùNp we have to either over-provision the error correcting capability of the code so as to deal with the occasionally large number of errors, waisting transmission rate most of the time, or we dimension the code for the typical case, but then we will not be able to decode when the number of errors is larger than the average. This means that short codes are either inefficient or unreliable (or both).

The general strategy for tackling this problem is to introduce more structure in the code definition, and to hope that such structure can be exploited for the encoding and the decoding. In the next section we shall describe a way of introducing structure that, while preserving Shannon‚Äôs idea of random codes, opens the way to efficient encoding/decoding.

There are two main ingredients that make modern coding work and the two are tightly connected. The first important ingredient is to use codes which can be described by local constraints only. The second ingredient is to use a local algorithm instead of an high complexity global one (namely symbol MAP or word MAP decoding). In this section we describe the first component.

3.1 Linear Codes

One of the simplest forms of structure consists in requiring ‚Ñ≠‚Ñ≠{\mathfrak{C}} to be a linear subspace of {ùü∂,ùü∑}Nsuperscript01ùëÅ\{{\tt 0},{\tt 1}\}^{N}. One speaks then of a linear code. For specifying such a code it is not necessary to list all the codewords. In fact, any linear space can be seen as the kernel of a matrix:

‚Ñ≠={x¬Ø‚àà{ùü∂,ùü∑}N:‚Ñç‚Äãx¬Ø=ùü∂¬Ø},‚Ñ≠conditional-set¬Øùë•superscript01ùëÅ‚Ñç¬Øùë•¬Ø0\displaystyle{\mathfrak{C}}=\left\{\underline{x}\in\{{\tt 0},{\tt 1}\}^{N}:\;{\mathbb{H}}\underline{x}=\underline{\tt 0}\right\}\,, (3.1)

where the matrix vector multiplication is assumed to be performed modulo 222. The matrix ‚Ñç‚Ñç{\mathbb{H}} is called the parity-check matrix. It has NùëÅN columns and we let M<NùëÄùëÅM<N denote its number of rows. Without loss of generality we can assume ‚Ñç‚Ñç{\mathbb{H}} to have maximum rank MùëÄM. As a consequence, ‚Ñ≠‚Ñ≠{\mathfrak{C}} is a linear space of dimension N‚àíMùëÅùëÄN-M. The rate of ‚Ñ≠‚Ñ≠{\mathfrak{C}} is

R=1‚àíMN.ùëÖ1ùëÄùëÅ\displaystyle R=1-\frac{M}{N}\,. (3.2)

The aùëéa-th line in ‚Ñç‚Äãx¬Ø=ùü∂¬Ø‚Ñç¬Øùë•¬Ø0{\mathbb{H}}\underline{x}=\underline{\tt 0} has the form (here and below ‚äïdirect-sum\oplus denotes modulo 222 addition)

xi1‚Äã(a)‚äï‚ãØ‚äïxik‚Äã(a)=ùü∂.direct-sumsubscriptùë•subscriptùëñ1ùëé‚ãØsubscriptùë•subscriptùëñùëòùëé0\displaystyle x_{i_{1}(a)}\oplus\cdots\oplus x_{i_{k}(a)}={\tt 0}. (3.3)

It is called a parity check.

The parity-check matrix is conveniently represented through a factor graph (also called Tanner graph). This is a bipartite graph including two types of nodes: MùëÄM function nodes (corresponding to the rows of ‚Ñç‚Ñç{\mathbb{H}}, or the parity-check equations) and NùëÅN variable nodes (for the columns of ‚Ñç‚Ñç{\mathbb{H}}, or the variables). Edges are drawn whenever the corresponding entry in ‚Ñç‚Ñç{\mathbb{H}} is non-vanishing.

  • Example 4: In Fig.¬†5 we draw the factor graph corresponding to the parity-check matrix (here N=7ùëÅ7N=7, M=3ùëÄ3M=3)

    ‚Ñç=[ùü∑ùü∂ùü∑ùü∂ùü∑ùü∂ùü∑ùü∂ùü∑ùü∑ùü∂ùü∂ùü∑ùü∑ùü∂ùü∂ùü∂ùü∑ùü∑ùü∑ùü∑].‚Ñçdelimited-[]101010101100110001111\displaystyle{\mathbb{H}}=\left[\begin{array}[]{ccccccc}{\tt 1}&{\tt 0}&{\tt 1}&{\tt 0}&{\tt 1}&{\tt 0}&{\tt 1}\\ {\tt 0}&{\tt 1}&{\tt 1}&{\tt 0}&{\tt 0}&{\tt 1}&{\tt 1}\\ {\tt 0}&{\tt 0}&{\tt 0}&{\tt 1}&{\tt 1}&{\tt 1}&{\tt 1}\end{array}\right]\,. (3.7)

In the following we shall use indices i,j,‚Ä¶ùëñùëó‚Ä¶i,j,\dots for variable nodes and a,b,‚Ä¶ùëéùëè‚Ä¶a,b,\dots for check nodes. We shall further denote by ‚àÇiùëñ\partial i (respectively, ‚àÇaùëé\partial a) the set of nodes that are adjacent to variable node iùëñi (to factor node aùëéa).

Remarkably, introducing the linear space structure does not deteriorate the performances of the resulting code. Let us introduce Shannon‚Äôs parity-check ensemble: it is defined by letting the parity-check matrix ‚Ñç‚Ñç{\mathbb{H}} be a uniformly random matrix with the prescribed dimensions. Explicitly, each of the N‚ÄãMùëÅùëÄNM entries Ha‚ÄãisubscriptùêªùëéùëñH_{ai} is an independent Bernoulli random variable of mean 1/2121/2. Probabilistic arguments similar to the ones for the random code ensemble can be developed for the random parity-check ensemble. The conclusion is that random codes from this ensemble allow to communicate with arbitrarily small block error probability at any rate R<ùô≤‚Äã(Q)ùëÖùô≤ùëÑR<{\tt C}(Q), where ùô≤‚Äã(Q)ùô≤ùëÑ{\tt C}(Q) is the capacity of the given BMS channel.

Unfortunately, linearity is not sufficient to guarantee that a code admits a low-complexity decoding algorithm. In particular, the algorithm which we discuss in the sequel works well only for codes that can be represented by a sparse parity-check matrix ‚Ñç‚Ñç{\mathbb{H}} (i.e. a parity check matrix with O‚Äã(N)ùëÇùëÅO(N) non-vanishing entries). Notice that a given code ‚Ñ≠‚Ñ≠{\mathfrak{C}} has more than one representation of the form (3.1). A priori one could hope that, given a uniformly random matrix ‚Ñç‚Ñç{\mathbb{H}}, a new matrix ‚Ñç‚Ä≤superscript‚Ñç‚Ä≤{\mathbb{H}}^{\prime} could be built such that ‚Ñç‚Ä≤superscript‚Ñç‚Ä≤{\mathbb{H}}^{\prime} is sparse and that its null space coincides with the one of ‚Ñç‚Ñç{\mathbb{H}}. This would provide a sparse representation of ‚Ñ≠‚Ñ≠{\mathfrak{C}}. Unfortunately, this is the case only for a vanishing fraction of matrices ‚Ñç‚Ñç{\mathbb{H}}, as shown by the exercise below.

  • Exercise 2: Consider a linear code ‚Ñ≠‚Ñ≠{\mathfrak{C}}, with blocklength NùëÅN, and dimension N‚àíMùëÅùëÄN-M (as a linear space). Prove the following sequence of arguments.

    • (i)ùëñ(i)

      The total number of binary N√óMùëÅùëÄN\times M parity-check matrices is 2N‚ÄãMsuperscript2ùëÅùëÄ2^{NM}.

    • (i‚Äãi)ùëñùëñ(ii)

      Each code ‚Ñ≠‚Ñ≠{\mathfrak{C}} has 2(M2)‚Äã‚àèi=1M(2i‚àí1)superscript2binomialùëÄ2superscriptsubscriptproductùëñ1ùëÄsuperscript2ùëñ12^{\binom{M}{2}}\prod_{i=1}^{M}\left(2^{i}-1\right) distinct N√óMùëÅùëÄN\times M parity-check matrices ‚Ñç‚Ñç{\mathbb{H}}.

    • (i‚Äãi‚Äãi)ùëñùëñùëñ(iii)

      The number of such matrices with at most a‚ÄãNùëéùëÅaN non-zero entries is ‚àëi=0a‚ÄãN(N‚ÄãMi)‚â§2N‚ÄãM‚Äãùî•2‚Äã(a/(N‚àíM))superscriptsubscriptùëñ0ùëéùëÅbinomialùëÅùëÄùëñsuperscript2ùëÅùëÄsubscriptùî•2ùëéùëÅùëÄ\sum_{i=0}^{aN}\binom{NM}{i}\leq 2^{NM{\mathfrak{h}}_{2}(a/(N-M))}.

    • (i‚Äãv)ùëñùë£(iv)

      Conclude from the above that, for any given aùëéa, the fraction of parity-check matrices ‚Ñç‚Ñç{\mathbb{H}} that admit a sparse representation in terms of a matrix ‚Ñç‚Ä≤superscript‚Ñç‚Ä≤{\mathbb{H}}^{\prime} with at most a‚ÄãNùëéùëÅaN ones, is of order e‚àíN‚ÄãŒ≥superscriptùëíùëÅùõæe^{-N\gamma} for some Œ≥>0ùõæ0\gamma>0.

With an abuse of language in the following we shall sometimes use the term ‚Äòcode‚Äô to denote a pair code/parity-check matrix.

3.2 Low-Density Parity-Check Codes

Further structure can be introduced by restricting the ensemble of parity-check matrices. Low-density parity-check (LDPC) codes are codes that have at least one sparse parity-check matrix.

Rather than considering the most general case let us limit ourselves to a particularly simple family of LDPC ensembles, originally introduced by Robert Gallager [19]. We call them ‚Äòregular‚Äô ensembles. An element in this family is characterized by the blocklength NùëÅN and two integer numbers kùëòk and lùëôl, with k>lùëòùëôk>l. We shall therefore refer to it as the (k,l)ùëòùëô(k,l) regular ensemble). In order to construct a random Tanner graph from this ensemble, one proceeds as follows:

  1. 1.

    Draw NùëÅN variable nodes, each attached to lùëôl half-edges and M=N‚Äãl/kùëÄùëÅùëôùëòM=Nl/k (we neglect here the possibility of N‚Äãl/kùëÅùëôùëòNl/k not being an integer) check nodes, each with kùëòk half edges.

  2. 2.

    Use an arbitrary convention to label the half edges form 111 to N‚ÄãlùëÅùëôNl, both on the variable node side as well as the check node side (note that this requires that M‚Äãk=N‚ÄãlùëÄùëòùëÅùëôMk=Nl).

  3. 3.

    Choose a permutation œÄùúã\pi uniformly at random among all permutations over N‚ÄãlùëÅùëôNl objects, and connect half edges accordingly.

Notice that the above procedure may give rise to multiple edges. Typically there will be O‚Äã(1)ùëÇ1O(1) multiple edges in a graph constructed as described. These can be eliminated easily without effecting the performance substantially. From the analytical point of view, a simple choice consists in eliminating all the edges (i,a)ùëñùëé(i,a) if (i,a)ùëñùëé(i,a) occurs an even number of times, and replacing them by a single occurrence (i,a)ùëñùëé(i,a) if it occurs an odd number of times.

Neglecting multiple occurrences (and the way to resolve them), the parity-check matrix corresponding to the graph constructed in this way does include kùëòk ones per row and lùëôl ones per column. In the sequel we will keep lùëôl and kùëòk fixed and consider the behavior of the ensemble as N‚Üí‚àû‚ÜíùëÅN\to\infty. This implies that the matrix has only O‚Äã(N)ùëÇùëÅO(N) non-vanishing entries. The matrix is sparse.

For practical purposes it is important to maximize the rate at which such codes enable one to communicate with vanishing error probability. To achieve this goal, several more complex ensembles have been introduced. As an example, one simple idea is to consider a generic row/column weight distribution (the weight being the number of non-zero elements), cf. Fig.¬†6 for an illustration. Such ensembles are usually referred to as ‚Äòirregular‚Äô, and were introduced in [27].

3.3 Weight Enumerator

As we saw in Section¬†2.5, the reason of the good performance of Shannon ensemble (having vanishing block error probability at rates arbitrarily close to the capacity), can be traced back to its minimum distance properties. This is indeed only a partial explanation (as we saw errors could be corrected well beyond half its minimum distance). It is nevertheless instructive and useful to understand the geometrical structure (and in particular the minimum distance properties) of typical codes from the LDPC ensembles defined above.

Let us start by noticing that, for linear codes, the distance enumerator does not depend upon the reference codeword. This is a straightforward consequence of the observation that, for any x¬Ø(0)‚àà‚Ñ≠superscript¬Øùë•0‚Ñ≠\underline{x}^{(0)}\in{\mathfrak{C}} the set x¬Ø(0)‚äï‚Ñ≠‚â°{x¬Ø(0)‚äïx¬Ø:x¬Ø‚àà‚Ñ≠}direct-sumsuperscript¬Øùë•0‚Ñ≠conditional-setdirect-sumsuperscript¬Øùë•0¬Øùë•¬Øùë•‚Ñ≠\underline{x}^{(0)}\oplus{\mathfrak{C}}\equiv\{\underline{x}^{(0)}\oplus\underline{x}\,:\,\underline{x}\in{\mathfrak{C}}\} coincides with ‚Ñ≠‚Ñ≠{\mathfrak{C}}. We are therefore led to consider the distance enumerator with respect to the all-zero codeword ùü∂¬Ø¬Ø0\underline{\tt 0}. This is also referred to as the weight enumerator,

ùí©‚Äã(w)=#‚Äã{x¬Ø‚àà‚Ñ≠:w‚Äã(x¬Ø)=w},ùí©ùë§#conditional-set¬Øùë•‚Ñ≠ùë§¬Øùë•ùë§\displaystyle{\cal N}(w)=\#\left\{\,\underline{x}\in{\mathfrak{C}}\,:\;\;w(\underline{x})=w\,\right\}\,, (3.8)

where w‚Äã(x¬Ø)=d‚Äã(x¬Ø,ùü∂¬Ø)ùë§¬Øùë•ùëë¬Øùë•¬Ø0w(\underline{x})=d(\underline{x},\underline{\tt 0}) is the number of non-zero entries in x¬Ø¬Øùë•\underline{x}.

ùí©¬Ø‚Äã(w)=(l‚Äãw)!‚Äã(F‚àíl‚Äãw)!F!‚Äã(Nw)‚Äãùñºùóàùñæùñøùñø‚Äã[qk‚Äã(z)M,zl‚Äãw].¬Øùí©ùë§ùëôùë§ùêπùëôùë§ùêπbinomialùëÅùë§ùñºùóàùñæùñøùñøsubscriptùëûùëòsuperscriptùëßùëÄsuperscriptùëßùëôùë§\displaystyle\overline{\cal N}(w)=\frac{(lw)!(F-lw)!}{F!}\binom{N}{w}\,{\sf coeff}[q_{k}(z)^{M},z^{lw}]\,. Here the integral runs over any path encircling the origin in the complex zùëßz plane. Evaluating the integral using the saddle point method we finally get ùí©¬Ø‚Äã(w)‚âêeN‚Äãœïapproaches-limit¬Øùí©ùë§superscriptùëíùëÅitalic-œï\overline{\cal N}(w)\doteq e^{N\phi}, where

œï‚Äã(œâ)‚â°(1‚àíl)‚Äãùî•‚Äã(œâ)+lk‚Äãlog‚Å°qk‚Äã(z)‚àíœâ‚Äãl‚Äãlog‚Å°z,italic-œïùúî1ùëôùî•ùúîùëôùëòsubscriptùëûùëòùëßùúîùëôùëß\displaystyle\phi(\omega)\equiv(1-l){\mathfrak{h}}(\omega)+\frac{l}{k}\log q_{k}(z)-\omega l\log z\,, (3.12)

and zùëßz is a solution of the saddle point equation

œâ=zk‚Äãqk‚Ä≤‚Äã(z)qk‚Äã(z).ùúîùëßùëòsubscriptsuperscriptùëû‚Ä≤ùëòùëßsubscriptùëûùëòùëß\displaystyle\omega=\frac{z}{k}\,\frac{q^{\prime}_{k}(z)}{q_{k}(z)}\,. (3.13)

The typical result of such a computation is shown in Fig.¬†7. As can be seen, there exists œâ‚àó>0subscriptùúî0\omega_{*}>0 such that œï‚Äã(œâ)<0italic-œïùúî0\phi(\omega)<0 for œâ‚àà(0,œâ‚àó)ùúî0subscriptùúî\omega\in(0,\omega_{*}). This implies that a typical code from this ensemble will not have any codeword of weight between 00 and N‚Äã(œâ‚àó‚àíŒµ)ùëÅsubscriptùúîùúÄN(\omega_{*}-\varepsilon). By linearity the minimum distance of the code is at least ‚âàN‚Äãœâ‚àóabsentùëÅsubscriptùúî\approx N\omega_{*}. This implies in particular that such codes can correct any error pattern over the binary symmetric channel of weight œâ‚àó/2subscriptùúî2\omega_{*}/2 or less.

Notice that œï‚Äã(œâ)italic-œïùúî\phi(\omega) is an ‚Äòannealed average‚Äô, in the terminology of disordered systems. As such, it can be dominated by rare instances in the ensemble. On the other hand, since log‚Å°ùí©N‚Äã(N‚Äãœâ)=Œò‚Äã(N)subscriptùí©ùëÅùëÅùúîŒòùëÅ\log{\cal N}_{N}(N\omega)=\Theta(N) is an ‚Äòextensive‚Äô quantity, we expect it to be self averaging in the language of statistical physics. In mathematics terms one says that it should concentrate in probability. Formally, this means that there exists a function Œ¶N‚Äã(œâ)subscriptŒ¶ùëÅùúî\Phi_{N}(\omega) that is non-random (i.e., does not depend upon the code) and such that

limN‚Üí‚àû‚Ñô‚Äã{|log‚Å°ùí©N‚Äã(N‚Äãœâ)‚àíŒ¶N‚Äã(œâ)|‚â•N‚ÄãŒ¥}=0.subscript‚ÜíùëÅ‚Ñôsubscriptùí©ùëÅùëÅùúîsubscriptŒ¶ùëÅùúîùëÅùõø0\displaystyle\lim_{N\to\infty}{\mathbb{P}}\left\{\left|\log{\cal N}_{N}(N\omega)-\Phi_{N}(\omega)\right|\geq N\delta\right\}=0\,. (3.14)

Further we expect that Œ¶N‚Äã(œâ)=N‚Äãœïq‚Äã(œâ)+o‚Äã(N)subscriptŒ¶ùëÅùúîùëÅsubscriptitalic-œïqùúîùëúùëÅ\Phi_{N}(\omega)=N\phi_{\rm q}(\omega)+o(N) as N‚Üí‚àû‚ÜíùëÅN\to\infty. Despite being rather fundamental, both these statements are open conjectures.

The coefficient œïq‚Äã(œâ)subscriptitalic-œïqùúî\phi_{\rm q}(\omega) is the growth rate of the weight enumerator for typical codes in the ensembles. In statistical mechanics terms, it is a ‚Äòquenched‚Äô free energy (or rather, entropy). By Jensen inequality œïq‚Äã(œâ)‚â§œï‚Äã(œâ)subscriptitalic-œïqùúîitalic-œïùúî\phi_{\rm q}(\omega)\leq\phi(\omega). A statistical mechanics calculation reveals that the inequality is strict for general (irregular) ensembles. On the other hand, for regular ensembles as the ones considered here, œïq‚Äã(œâ)=œï‚Äã(œâ)subscriptitalic-œïqùúîitalic-œïùúî\phi_{\rm q}(\omega)=\phi(\omega): the annealed calculation yields the correct exponential rate. This claim has been supported rigorously by the results of [47, 3, 31].

Let us finally comment on the relation between distance enumerator and the Franz-Parisi potential [18], introduced in the study of glassy systems. In this context the potential is used to probe the structure of the Boltzmann measure. One considers a system with energy function E‚Äã(x)ùê∏ùë•E(x), a reference configuration x0subscriptùë•0x_{0} and some notion of distance between configurations d‚Äã(x,x‚Ä≤)ùëëùë•superscriptùë•‚Ä≤d(x,x^{\prime}). The constrained partition function is then defined as

Z‚Äã(x0,w)=‚à´e‚àíE‚Äã(x)‚ÄãŒ¥‚Äã(d‚Äã(x0,x)‚àíw)‚Äãdx.ùëçsubscriptùë•0ùë§superscriptùëíùê∏ùë•ùõøùëësubscriptùë•0ùë•ùë§differential-dùë•\displaystyle Z(x_{0},w)=\int e^{-E(x)}\,\delta(d(x_{0},x)-w)\;{\rm d}x\,. (3.15)

One then defines the potential Œ¶N‚Äã(œâ)subscriptŒ¶ùëÅùúî\Phi_{N}(\omega) as the typical value of log‚Å°Z‚Äã(x0,w)ùëçsubscriptùë•0ùë§\log Z(x_{0},w) when x0subscriptùë•0x_{0} is a random configuration with the same Boltzmann distribution and w=N‚Äãœâùë§ùëÅùúîw=N\omega. Self averaging is expected to hold here too:

limN‚Üí‚àû‚Ñôx0‚Äã{|log‚Å°Z‚Äã(x0,N‚Äãœâ)‚àíŒ¶N‚Äã(œâ)|‚â•N‚ÄãŒ¥}=0.subscript‚ÜíùëÅsubscript‚Ñôsubscriptùë•0ùëçsubscriptùë•0ùëÅùúîsubscriptŒ¶ùëÅùúîùëÅùõø0\displaystyle\lim_{N\to\infty}{\mathbb{P}}_{x_{0}}\left\{\,\left|\log Z(x_{0},N\omega)-\Phi_{N}(\omega)\right|\geq N\delta\,\right\}=0\,. (3.16)

Here NùëÅN may denote the number of particles or the volume of the system and ‚Ñôx0‚Äã{‚ãØ}subscript‚Ñôsubscriptùë•0‚ãØ{\mathbb{P}}_{x_{0}}\left\{\,\cdots\,\right\} indicates probability with respect to x0subscriptùë•0x_{0} distributed with the Boltzmann measure for the energy function E‚Äã(x0)ùê∏subscriptùë•0E(x_{0}).

It is clear that the two ideas are strictly related and can be generalized to any joint distribution of NùëÅN variables (x1,‚Ä¶,xN)subscriptùë•1‚Ä¶subscriptùë•ùëÅ(x_{1},\dots,x_{N}). In both cases the structure of such a distribution is probed by picking a reference configuration and restricting the measure to its neighborhood.

To be more specific, the weight enumerator can be seen as a special case of the Franz-Parisi potential. It is sufficient to take as Boltzmann distribution the uniform measure over codewords of a linear code ‚Ñ≠‚Ñ≠{\mathfrak{C}}. In other words, let the configurations be binary strings of length NùëÅN, and set E‚Äã(x¬Ø)=0ùê∏¬Øùë•0E(\underline{x})=0 if x¬Ø‚àà‚Ñ≠¬Øùë•‚Ñ≠\underline{x}\in{\mathfrak{C}}, and =‚àûabsent=\infty otherwise. Then the restricted partition function is just the distance enumerator with respect to the reference codeword, which indeed does not depend on it.

4 The Decoding Problem for Sparse Graph Codes

As we have already seen, MAP decoding requires computing either marginals or the mode of the conditional distribution of x¬Ø¬Øùë•\underline{x} being the channel input given output y¬Ø¬Øùë¶\underline{y}. In the case of LDPC codes the posterior probability distribution factorizes according to underlying factor graph Gùê∫G:

Œº‚Ñ≠,y‚Äã(x¬Ø)=1Z‚Äã(‚Ñ≠,y)‚Äã‚àèi=1NQ‚Äã(yi|xi)‚Äã‚àèa=1MùïÄ‚Äã(xi1‚Äã(a)‚äï‚ãØ‚äïxik‚Äã(a)=ùü∂).subscriptùúá‚Ñ≠ùë¶¬Øùë•1ùëç‚Ñ≠ùë¶superscriptsubscriptproductùëñ1ùëÅùëÑconditionalsubscriptùë¶ùëñsubscriptùë•ùëñsuperscriptsubscriptproductùëé1ùëÄùïÄdirect-sumsubscriptùë•subscriptùëñ1ùëé‚ãØsubscriptùë•subscriptùëñùëòùëé0\displaystyle\mu_{{\mathfrak{C}},y}(\underline{x})=\frac{1}{Z({\mathfrak{C}},y)}\,\prod_{i=1}^{N}Q(y_{i}|x_{i})\,\prod_{a=1}^{M}{\mathbb{I}}(x_{i_{1}(a)}\oplus\cdots\oplus x_{i_{k}(a)}={\tt 0})\,. (4.1)

Here (i1‚Äã(a),‚Ä¶,ik‚Äã(a))subscriptùëñ1ùëé‚Ä¶subscriptùëñùëòùëé(i_{1}(a),\dots,i_{k}(a)) denotes the set of variable indices involved in the aùëéa-th parity check (i.e., the non-zero entries in the aùëéa-th row of the parity-check matrix ‚Ñç‚Ñç{\mathbb{H}}). In the language of spin models, the terms Q‚Äã(yi|xi)ùëÑconditionalsubscriptùë¶ùëñsubscriptùë•ùëñQ(y_{i}|x_{i}) correspond to an external random field. The factors ùïÄ‚Äã(xi1‚Äã(a)‚äï‚ãØ‚äïxik‚Äã(a)=ùü∂)ùïÄdirect-sumsubscriptùë•subscriptùëñ1ùëé‚ãØsubscriptùë•subscriptùëñùëòùëé0{\mathbb{I}}(x_{i_{1}(a)}\oplus\cdots\oplus x_{i_{k}(a)}={\tt 0}) can instead be regarded as hard core kùëòk-spins interactions. Under the mapping œÉi=(‚àí1)xisubscriptùúéùëñsuperscript1subscriptùë•ùëñ\sigma_{i}=(-1)^{x_{i}}, such interactions depend on the spins through the product œÉi1‚Äã(a)‚Äã‚ãØ‚ÄãœÉik‚Äã(a)subscriptùúésubscriptùëñ1ùëé‚ãØsubscriptùúésubscriptùëñùëòùëé\sigma_{i_{1}(a)}\cdots\sigma_{i_{k}(a)}. The model (4.1) maps therefore onto a kùëòk-spin model with random field.

For MAP decoding, minimum distance properties of the code play a crucial role in determining the performances. We investigated such properties in the previous section. Unfortunately, there is no known way of implementing MAP decoding efficiently. In this section we discuss two decoding algorithms that exploit the sparseness of the factor graph to achieve efficient decoding. Although such strategies are sub-optimal with respect to word (or symbol) MAP decoding, the graphical structure can itself be optimized, leading to state-of-the-art performances.

After briefly discussing bit-flipping decoding, most of this section will be devoted to message passing that is the approach most used in practice. Remarkably, both bit flipping as well as message passing are closely related to statistical mechanics.

4.1 Bit Flipping

For the sake of simplicity, let us assume that communication takes place over a binary symmetric channel. We receive the message y¬Ø‚àà{ùü∂,ùü∑}N¬Øùë¶superscript01ùëÅ\underline{y}\in\{{\tt 0},{\tt 1}\}^{N} and try to find the transmitted codeword x¬Ø¬Øùë•\underline{x} as follows:

  1. Bit-flipping decoder

  2. 0.

    Set x¬Ø‚Äã(0)=y¬Ø¬Øùë•0¬Øùë¶\underline{x}(0)=\underline{y}.

  3. 1.

    Find a bit belonging to more unsatisfied than satisfied parity checks.

  4. 2.

    If such a bit exists, flip it: xi‚Äã(t+1)=xi‚Äã(t)‚äïùü∑subscriptùë•ùëñùë°1direct-sumsubscriptùë•ùëñùë°1x_{i}(t+1)=x_{i}(t)\oplus{\tt 1}. Keep the other bits: xj‚Äã(t+1)=xj‚Äã(t)subscriptùë•ùëóùë°1subscriptùë•ùëóùë°x_{j}(t+1)=x_{j}(t) for all j‚â†iùëóùëñj\neq i.
    If there is no such bit, return x¬Ø‚Äã(t)¬Øùë•ùë°\underline{x}(t) and halt.

  5. 3.

    Repeat steps 1 and 2.

The bit to be flipped is usually chosen uniformly at random among the ones satisfying the condition at step 1. However this is irrelevant for the analysis below.

In order to monitor the bit-flipping algorithm, it is useful to introduce the function:

U‚Äã(t)‚â°#‚Äã{¬†parity-check equations not satisfied by¬†x¬Ø‚Äã(t)¬†}.ùëàùë°#¬†parity-check equations not satisfied by¬†x¬Ø(t)¬†\displaystyle U(t)\equiv\#\left\{\mbox{ parity-check equations not satisfied by $\underline{x}(t)$\, }\right\}\,. (4.2)

This is a non-negative integer, and if U‚Äã(t)=0ùëàùë°0U(t)=0 the algorithm is halted and it outputs x¬Ø‚Äã(t)¬Øùë•ùë°\underline{x}(t). Furthermore, U‚Äã(t)ùëàùë°U(t) cannot be larger than the number of parity checks MùëÄM and decreases (by at least one) at each cycle. Therefore, the algorithm complexity is O‚Äã(N)ùëÇùëÅO(N) (this is a commonly regarded as the ultimate goal for many communication problems).

It remains to be seen if the output of the bit-flipping algorithm is related to the transmitted codeword. In Fig.¬†8 we present the results of a numerical experiment. We considered the (5,10)510(5,10) regular ensemble and generated about 100010001000 random code and channel realizations for each value of the noise level pùëùp in some mesh. Then, we applied the above algorithm and traced the fraction of successfully decoded blocks, as well as the residual energy U‚àó=U‚Äã(t‚àó)subscriptùëàùëàsubscriptùë°U_{*}=U(t_{*}), where t‚àósubscriptùë°t_{*} is the total number of iterations of the algorithm. The data suggests that bit-flipping is able to overcome a finite noise level: it recovers the original message with high probability when less than about 2.5%percent2.52.5\% of the bits are corrupted by the channel. Furthermore, the curves for the block error probability PBbfsuperscriptsubscriptPBbf{\rm P}_{{\rm B}}^{\rm bf} under bit-flipping decoding become steeper and steeper as the system size is increased. It is natural to conjecture that asymptotically, a phase transition takes place at a well defined noise level pbfsubscriptùëùbfp_{\rm bf}: PBbf‚Üí0‚ÜísuperscriptsubscriptPBbf0{\rm P}_{{\rm B}}^{\rm bf}\to 0 for p<pbfùëùsubscriptùëùbfp<p_{\rm bf} and PBbf‚Üí1‚ÜísuperscriptsubscriptPBbf1{\rm P}_{{\rm B}}^{\rm bf}\to 1 for p>pbfùëùsubscriptùëùbfp>p_{\rm bf}. Numerically pbf=0.025¬±0.005subscriptùëùbfplus-or-minus0.0250.005p_{\rm bf}=0.025\pm 0.005.

This threshold can be compared with the one for word MAP decoding, that we will call pcsubscriptùëùcp_{\rm c}: The bounds in [60] state that 0.108188‚â§pc‚â§0.1091610.108188subscriptùëùc0.1091610.108188\leq p_{\rm c}\leq 0.109161 for the (5,10)510(5,10) ensemble, while a statistical mechanics calculation yields pc‚âà0.1091subscriptùëùc0.1091p_{\rm c}\approx 0.1091. Bit-flipping is significantly sub-optimal, but it is still surprisingly good, given the extreme simplicity of the algorithm.

These numerical findings can be confirmed rigorously [55].

Theorem 4.1.

Consider a regular (l,k)ùëôùëò(l,k) LDPC ensemble and let ‚Ñ≠‚Ñ≠{\mathfrak{C}} be chosen uniformly at random from the ensemble. If l‚â•5ùëô5l\geq 5 then there exists Œµ>0ùúÄ0\varepsilon>0 such that, with high probability, Bit-flipping is able to correct any pattern of at most N‚ÄãŒµùëÅùúÄN\varepsilon errors produced by a binary symmetric channel.

Given a generic word x¬Ø¬Øùë•\underline{x} (i.e., a length NùëÅN binary string that is not necessarily a codeword), let us denote, with a slight abuse of notation, by U‚Äã(x¬Ø)ùëà¬Øùë•U(\underline{x}) the number of parity-check equations that are not satisfied by x¬Ø¬Øùë•\underline{x}. The above result, together with the weight enumerator calculation in the previous section, suggests the following picture of the function U‚Äã(x¬Ø)ùëà¬Øùë•U(\underline{x}). If x¬Ø(0)‚àà‚Ñ≠superscript¬Øùë•0‚Ñ≠\underline{x}^{(0)}\in{\mathfrak{C}}, than U‚Äã(x¬Ø(0))=0ùëàsuperscript¬Øùë•00U(\underline{x}^{(0)})=0. Moving away from x¬Ø(0)superscript¬Øùë•0\underline{x}^{(0)}, U‚Äã(x¬Ø)ùëà¬Øùë•U(\underline{x}) will become strictly positive. However as long as d‚Äã(x¬Ø(0),x¬Ø)ùëësuperscript¬Øùë•0¬Øùë•d(\underline{x}^{(0)},\underline{x}) is small enough, U‚Äã(x¬Ø)ùëà¬Øùë•U(\underline{x}) does not have any local minimum distinct from x¬Ø(0)superscript¬Øùë•0\underline{x}^{(0)}. A greedy procedure with a starting point within such a Hamming radius is able to reconstruct x¬Ø(0)superscript¬Øùë•0\underline{x}^{(0)}. As we move further away, U‚Äã(x¬Ø)ùëà¬Øùë•U(\underline{x}) stays positive (no other codewords are encountered) but local minima start to appear. Bit flipping gets trapped in such minima. Finally, for d‚Äã(x¬Ø(0),x¬Ø)‚â•N‚Äãœâ‚àóùëësuperscript¬Øùë•0¬Øùë•ùëÅsubscriptùúîd(\underline{x}^{(0)},\underline{x})\geq N\omega_{*} new codewords, i.e., minima with U‚Äã(x¬Ø)=0ùëà¬Øùë•0U(\underline{x})=0, are encountered.

4.2 Message Passing

Message-passing algorithms are iterative and have low complexity. Unlike the bit-flipping procedure in the previous section, the basic variables are now associated to directed edges in the factor graph. More precisely, for each edge (i,a)ùëñùëé(i,a) (corresponding to a non-zero entry in the parity-check matrix at row aùëéa and column iùëñi), we introduce two messages ŒΩi‚Üíasubscriptùúà‚Üíùëñùëé\nu_{i\to a} and ŒΩ^a‚Üíisubscript^ùúà‚Üíùëéùëñ\widehat{\nu}_{a\to i}. Messages are elements of some set (the message alphabet) that we shall denote by ùñ¨ùñ¨{\sf M}. Depending on the specific algorithm, ùñ¨ùñ¨{\sf M} can have finite cardinality, or be infinite, for instance ùñ¨=‚Ñùùñ¨‚Ñù{\sf M}={\mathbb{R}}. Since the algorithm is iterative, it is convenient to introduce a time index t=0,1,2,‚Ä¶ùë°012‚Ä¶t=0,1,2,\dots and label the messages with the time at which they are updated: ŒΩi‚Üía(t)subscriptsuperscriptùúàùë°‚Üíùëñùëé\nu^{(t)}_{i\to a} and ŒΩ^a‚Üíi(t)subscriptsuperscript^ùúàùë°‚Üíùëéùëñ\widehat{\nu}^{(t)}_{a\to i} (but we will sometimes drop the label below).

The defining property of message-passing algorithms is that the message flowing from node uùë¢u to vùë£v at a given time is a function of messages entering uùë¢u from nodes wùë§w distinct from vùë£v at the previous time step. Formally, the algorithm is defined in terms of two sets of functions Œ¶i‚Üía‚Äã(‚ãÖ)subscriptŒ¶‚Üíùëñùëé‚ãÖ\Phi_{i\to a}(\,\cdot\,), Œ®a‚Üíi‚Äã(‚ãÖ)subscriptŒ®‚Üíùëéùëñ‚ãÖ\Psi_{a\to i}(\,\cdot\,), that define the update operations at variable and function nodes as follows

ŒΩi‚Üía(t+1)=Œ¶i‚Üía‚Äã({ŒΩ^b‚Üíi(t);b‚àà‚àÇi\a};yi),ŒΩ^a‚Üíi(t)=Œ®a‚Üíi‚Äã({ŒΩj‚Üía(t);j‚àà‚àÇa\i}).formulae-sequencesuperscriptsubscriptùúà‚Üíùëñùëéùë°1subscriptŒ¶‚Üíùëñùëésubscriptsuperscript^ùúàùë°‚Üíùëèùëñùëè\ùëñùëésubscriptùë¶ùëñsuperscriptsubscript^ùúà‚Üíùëéùëñùë°subscriptŒ®‚Üíùëéùëñsubscriptsuperscriptùúàùë°‚Üíùëóùëéùëó\ùëéùëñ\displaystyle\nu_{i\to a}^{(t+1)}=\Phi_{i\to a}(\{\widehat{\nu}^{(t)}_{b\to i};b\in\partial i\backslash a\};y_{i})\,,\;\;\;\;\;\;\;\;\;\widehat{\nu}_{a\to i}^{(t)}=\Psi_{a\to i}(\{\nu^{(t)}_{j\to a};j\in\partial a\backslash i\})\,. (4.3)

Notice that messages are updated in parallel and that the time counter is incremented only at variable nodes. Alternative scheduling schemes can be considered but we will stick to this for the sake of simplicity. After a pre-established number of iterations, the transmitted bits are estimated using all the messages incoming at the corresponding nodes. More precisely, the estimate at function iùëñi is defined through a new function

A graphical representation of message passing updates is provided in Fig.¬†10.

The most prominent instance of a message-passing algorithm is the Belief Propagation (BP) algorithm. In this case the messages ŒΩi‚Üía(t)‚Äã(xi)superscriptsubscriptùúà‚Üíùëñùëéùë°subscriptùë•ùëñ\nu_{i\to a}^{(t)}(x_{i}) and ŒΩ^a‚Üíi(t)‚Äã(xi)superscriptsubscript^ùúà‚Üíùëéùëñùë°subscriptùë•ùëñ\widehat{\nu}_{a\to i}^{(t)}(x_{i}) are distributions over the bit variables xi‚àà{ùü∂,ùü∑}subscriptùë•ùëñ01x_{i}\in\{{\tt 0},{\tt 1}\}. The message ŒΩ^a‚Üíi(t)‚Äã(xi)superscriptsubscript^ùúà‚Üíùëéùëñùë°subscriptùë•ùëñ\widehat{\nu}_{a\to i}^{(t)}(x_{i}) is usually interpreted as the a posteriori distributions of the bit xisubscriptùë•ùëñx_{i} given the information coming from edge a‚Üíi‚Üíùëéùëña\to i. Analogously, ŒΩi‚Üía‚Äã(xi)subscriptùúà‚Üíùëñùëésubscriptùë•ùëñ\nu_{i\to a}(x_{i}) is interpreted as the a posteriori distribution of xisubscriptùë•ùëñx_{i}, given all the information collected through edges distinct from (a,i)ùëéùëñ(a,i). Since the messages normalization (explicitly ŒΩi‚Üía‚Äã(ùü∂)+ŒΩi‚Üía‚Äã(ùü∑)=1subscriptùúà‚Üíùëñùëé0subscriptùúà‚Üíùëñùëé11\nu_{i\to a}({\tt 0})+\nu_{i\to a}({\tt 1})=1) can be enforced at any time, we shall neglect overall factors in writing down the relation between to messages (and correspondingly, we shall use the symbol ‚àùproportional-to\propto).

4.3 Correctness of Belief Propagation on Trees

The justification for the BP update equations (4.5), (4.6) lies in the observation that, whenever the underlying factor graph is a tree, the estimated marginal ŒΩi(t)‚Äã(xi)superscriptsubscriptùúàùëñùë°subscriptùë•ùëñ\nu_{i}^{(t)}(x_{i}) converges after a finite number of iterations to the correct one Œºi‚Äã(xi)subscriptùúáùëñsubscriptùë•ùëñ\mu_{i}(x_{i}). In particular, under the tree assumption, and for any tùë°t sufficiently large, x^i(t)‚Äã(y¬Ø)subscriptsuperscript^ùë•ùë°ùëñ¬Øùë¶\widehat{x}^{(t)}_{i}(\underline{y}) coincides with the symbol MAP decision.

In order to prove this statement, consider a tree factor graph Gùê∫G. Given a couple of adjacent nodes u,vùë¢ùë£u,v, denote by G‚Äã(u‚Üív)ùê∫‚Üíùë¢ùë£G(u\to v) the subtree rooted at the directed edge u‚Üív‚Üíùë¢ùë£u\to v (this contains all that can be reached from vùë£v through a non-reversing path whose first step is v‚Üíu‚Üíùë£ùë¢v\to u). If iùëñi is a variable index and aùëéa a parity-check index, let Œºi‚Üía‚Äã(‚ãÖ)subscriptùúá‚Üíùëñùëé‚ãÖ\mu_{i\to a}(\,\cdot\,) be the measure over x¬Ø={xj:j‚ààG‚Äã(i‚Üía)}¬Øùë•conditional-setsubscriptùë•ùëóùëóùê∫‚Üíùëñùëé\underline{x}=\{x_{j}:\,j\in G(i\to a)\}, that is obtained by retaining in Eq.¬†(4.1) only those terms that are related to nodes in G‚Äã(i‚Üía)ùê∫‚ÜíùëñùëéG(i\to a):

Œºi‚Üía‚Äã(x¬Ø)=1Z‚Äã(i‚Üía)‚Äã‚àèj‚ààG‚Äã(i‚Üía)Q‚Äã(yi|xi)‚Äã‚àèb‚ààG‚Äã(i‚Üía)ùïÄ‚Äã(xi1‚Äã(b)‚äï‚ãØ‚äïxik‚Äã(b)=ùü∂).subscriptùúá‚Üíùëñùëé¬Øùë•1ùëç‚Üíùëñùëésubscriptproductùëóùê∫‚ÜíùëñùëéùëÑconditionalsubscriptùë¶ùëñsubscriptùë•ùëñsubscriptproductùëèùê∫‚ÜíùëñùëéùïÄdirect-sumsubscriptùë•subscriptùëñ1ùëè‚ãØsubscriptùë•subscriptùëñùëòùëè0\displaystyle\mu_{i\to a}(\underline{x})=\frac{1}{Z(i\to a)}\,\prod_{j\in G(i\to a)}Q(y_{i}|x_{i})\;\prod_{b\in G(i\to a)}{\mathbb{I}}(x_{i_{1}(b)}\oplus\cdots\oplus x_{i_{k}(b)}={\tt 0})\,. (4.15)

The measure Œº^a‚Üíi‚Äã(‚ãÖ)subscript^ùúá‚Üíùëéùëñ‚ãÖ\widehat{\mu}_{a\to i}(\,\cdot\,) is defined analogously for the subtree G‚Äã(a‚Üíi)ùê∫‚ÜíùëéùëñG(a\to i). The marginals Œºi‚Üía‚Äã(xi)subscriptùúá‚Üíùëñùëésubscriptùë•ùëñ\mu_{i\to a}(x_{i}) (respectively Œº^a‚Üíi‚Äã(xi)subscript^ùúá‚Üíùëéùëñsubscriptùë•ùëñ\widehat{\mu}_{a\to i}(x_{i})) are easily seen to satisfy the recursions

Œºi‚Üía‚Äã(xi)subscriptùúá‚Üíùëñùëésubscriptùë•ùëñ\displaystyle\mu_{i\to a}(x_{i}) ‚àùproportional-to\displaystyle\propto Q‚Äã(yi|xi)‚Äã‚àèb‚àà‚àÇi\aŒº^b‚Üíi‚Äã(xi),ùëÑconditionalsubscriptùë¶ùëñsubscriptùë•ùëñsubscriptproductùëè\ùëñùëésubscript^ùúá‚Üíùëèùëñsubscriptùë•ùëñ\displaystyle Q(y_{i}|x_{i})\!\prod_{b\in\partial i\backslash a}\widehat{\mu}_{b\to i}(x_{i})\,, (4.16)
Œº^a‚Üíi‚Äã(xi)subscript^ùúá‚Üíùëéùëñsubscriptùë•ùëñ\displaystyle\widehat{\mu}_{a\to i}(x_{i}) ‚àùproportional-to\displaystyle\propto ‚àë{xj}ùïÄ‚Äã(xi‚äïxj1‚äï‚ãØ‚äïxjk‚àí1=ùü∂)‚Äã‚àèj‚àà‚àÇa\iŒºj‚Üía‚Äã(xj),subscriptsubscriptùë•ùëóùïÄdirect-sumsubscriptùë•ùëñsubscriptùë•subscriptùëó1‚ãØsubscriptùë•subscriptùëóùëò10subscriptproductùëó\ùëéùëñsubscriptùúá‚Üíùëóùëésubscriptùë•ùëó\displaystyle\sum_{\{x_{j}\}}{\mathbb{I}}(x_{i}\oplus x_{j_{1}}\oplus\cdots\oplus x_{j_{k-1}}={\tt 0})\prod_{j\in\partial a\backslash i}\mu_{j\to a}(x_{j})\,, (4.17)

which coincide, apart from the time index, with the BP recursion (4.5), (4.6). That such recursions converges to {Œºi‚Üía‚Äã(xi),Œº^a‚Üíi‚Äã(xi)}subscriptùúá‚Üíùëñùëésubscriptùë•ùëñsubscript^ùúá‚Üíùëéùëñsubscriptùë•ùëñ\{\mu_{i\to a}(x_{i}),\widehat{\mu}_{a\to i}(x_{i})\} follows by induction over the tree depth.

In statistical mechanics equations similar to (4.16), (4.17) are often written as recursions on the constrained partition function. They allow to solve exactly models on trees. However they have been often applied as mean-field approximation to statistical models on non-tree graphs. This is often referred to as the Bethe-Peierls approximation [8].

The Bethe approximation presents several advantages with respect to ‚Äònaive-mean field‚Äô [61] (that amounts to writing ‚Äòself-consistency‚Äô equations for expectations over single degrees of freedom). It retains correlations among degrees of freedom that interact directly, and is exact on some non-empty graph (trees). It is often asymptotically (in the large size limit) exact on locally tree-like graphs. Finally, it is quantitatively more accurate for non-tree like graphs and offers a much richer modeling palette.

Within the theory of disordered systems (especially, glass models on sparse random graphs), Eqs.¬†(4.16) and (4.17) are also referred to as the cavity equations. With respect to Bethe-Peierls, the cavity approach includes a hierarchy of (‚Äòreplica symmetry breaking‚Äô) refinements of such equations that aim at capturing long range correlations [37]. This will briefly described in Section 5.

We should finally mention that several improvements over Bethe approximation have been developed within statistical physics. Among them, Kikuchi‚Äôs cluster variational method [24] is worth mentioning since it motivated the development of a ‚Äògeneralized belief propagation‚Äô algorithm, which spurred a lot of interest within the artificial intelligence community [61].

4.4 Density Evolution

Although BP converges to the exact marginals on tree graphs, this says little about its performances on practical codes such as the LDPC ensembles introduced in Section¬†3. Fortunately, a rather precise picture on the performance of LDPC ensembles can be derived in the large blocklength limit N‚Üí‚àû‚ÜíùëÅN\to\infty. The basic reason for this is that the corresponding random factor graph is locally tree-like with high probability if we consider large blocklengths.

Before elaborating on this point, notice that the performance under BP decoding (e.g., the bit error rate) is independent on the transmitted codeword. For the sake of analysis, we shall hereafter assume that the all-zero codeword ùü∂¬Ø¬Ø0\underline{\tt 0} has been transmitted.

Consider a factor graph Gùê∫G and let (i,a)ùëñùëé(i,a) be one of its edges. Consider the message ŒΩi‚Üía(t)subscriptsuperscriptùúàùë°‚Üíùëñùëé\nu^{(t)}_{i\to a} sent by the BP decoder in iteration tùë°t along edge (i,a)ùëñùëé(i,a). A considerable amount of information is contained in the distribution of ŒΩi‚Üía(t)subscriptsuperscriptùúàùë°‚Üíùëñùëé\nu^{(t)}_{i\to a} with respect to the channel realization, as well as in the analogous distribution for ŒΩ^a‚Üíi(t)subscriptsuperscript^ùúàùë°‚Üíùëéùëñ\widehat{\nu}^{(t)}_{a\to i}. To see this, note that under the all-zero codeword assumption, the bit error rate after tùë°t iterations is given by

Pb(t)=1n‚Äã‚àëi=1n‚Ñô‚Äã{Œ¶i‚Äã({ŒΩ^b‚Üíi(t);b‚àà‚àÇi};yi)‚â†ùü∂}.superscriptsubscriptPbùë°1ùëõsuperscriptsubscriptùëñ1ùëõ‚ÑôsubscriptŒ¶ùëñsuperscriptsubscript^ùúà‚Üíùëèùëñùë°ùëèùëñsubscriptùë¶ùëñ0\displaystyle{\rm P}_{{\rm b}}^{(t)}=\frac{1}{n}\sum_{i=1}^{n}{\mathbb{P}}\left\{\Phi_{i}(\{\widehat{\nu}_{b\to i}^{(t)};b\in\partial i\};y_{i})\neq{\tt 0}\right\}\,. (4.18)

Therefore, if the messages ŒΩ^b‚Üíi(t)superscriptsubscript^ùúà‚Üíùëèùëñùë°\widehat{\nu}_{b\to i}^{(t)} are independent, then the bit error probability is determined by the distribution of ŒΩ^a‚Üíi(t)subscriptsuperscript^ùúàùë°‚Üíùëéùëñ\widehat{\nu}^{(t)}_{a\to i}.

Rather than considering one particular graph (code) and a specific edge, it is much simpler to take the average over all edges and all graph realizations. We thus consider the distribution ùñ∫t(N)‚Äã(‚ãÖ)superscriptsubscriptùñ∫ùë°ùëÅ‚ãÖ{\sf a}_{t}^{(N)}(\,\cdot\,) of ŒΩi‚Üía(t)subscriptsuperscriptùúàùë°‚Üíùëñùëé\nu^{(t)}_{i\to a} with respect to the channel, the edges, and the graph realization. While this is still a quite difficult object to study rigorously, it is on the other hand possible to characterize its large blocklength limit ùñ∫t‚Äã(‚ãÖ)=limNùñ∫t(N)‚Äã(‚ãÖ)subscriptùñ∫ùë°‚ãÖsubscriptùëÅsuperscriptsubscriptùñ∫ùë°ùëÅ‚ãÖ{\sf a}_{t}(\,\cdot\,)=\lim_{N}{\sf a}_{t}^{(N)}(\,\cdot\,). This distribution satisfies a simple recursion.

It is convenient to introduce the directed neighborhood of radius rùëür of the directed edge i‚Üía‚Üíùëñùëéi\to a in Gùê∫G, call it ùñ°i‚Üía‚Äã(r;G)subscriptùñ°‚Üíùëñùëéùëüùê∫{\sf B}_{i\to a}(r;G). This is defined as the subgraph of FùêπF that includes all the variable nodes that can be reached from iùëñi through a non-reversing path of length at most rùëür, whose first step is not the edge (i,a)ùëñùëé(i,a). It includes as well all the function nodes connected only to the above specified variable nodes. In Fig.¬†13 we reproduce an example of a directed neighborhood of radius r=3ùëü3r=3 (for illustrative purposes we also include the edge (i,a)ùëñùëé(i,a)) in a (2,3)23(2,3) regular code.

If FùêπF is the factor graph of a random code from the (k,l)ùëòùëô(k,l) LDPC ensemble, then ùñ°i‚Üía‚Äã(r;F)subscriptùñ°‚Üíùëñùëéùëüùêπ{\sf B}_{i\to a}(r;F) is with high probability a depth-rùëür regular tree with degree lùëôl at variable nodes and degree kùëòk at check nodes (as in Fig.¬†13 where l=2ùëô2l=2 and k=3ùëò3k=3). The basic reason for this phenomenon is rather straightforward. Imagine to explore the neighborhood progressively, moving away from the root, in a breadth first fashion. At any finite radius rùëür, about cr/NsuperscriptùëêùëüùëÅc^{r}/N vertices have been visited (here c=(k‚àí1)‚Äã(l‚àí1)ùëêùëò1ùëô1c=(k-1)(l-1)). The vertices encountered at the next layer will be ‚Äòmore or less‚Äô uniformly random among all the ones not visited so far. As a consequence they will be distinct with high probability, and ùñ°i‚Üía‚Äã(r+1;G)subscriptùñ°‚Üíùëñùëéùëü1ùê∫{\sf B}_{i\to a}(r+1;G) will be a tree as well. This argument breaks down when the probability that two of the Œò‚Äã(cr)Œòsuperscriptùëêùëü\Theta(c^{r}) new vertices coincide, that is for c2‚Äãr=Œò‚Äã(N)superscriptùëê2ùëüŒòùëÅc^{2r}=\Theta(N).101010This is the famous birthday problem. The probability that two out of a party of nùëõn peoples were born on the same day of the year, scales like n2/Nsuperscriptùëõ2ùëÅn^{2}/N for n2‚â™Nmuch-less-thansuperscriptùëõ2ùëÅn^{2}\ll N (NùëÅN is here the number of days in a year). This is equivalent to r‚âÉ12‚Äãlogc‚Å°Nsimilar-to-or-equalsùëü12subscriptùëêùëÅr\simeq\frac{1}{2}\log_{c}N.

Let ŒΩ(t)superscriptùúàùë°\nu^{(t)} be the message passed through the root edge of such a tree after tùë°t BP iterations. Equations (4.19), or the sequence of distributions that they define, are usually referred to as density evolution. The name is motivated by the identification of the random variables with their densities (even if these do not necessarily exist). They should be parsed as follows (we are refer here to the first equation in (4.19); an analogous phrasing holds for the second): pick l‚àí1ùëô1l-1 i.i.d. copies ŒΩ^(t)superscript^ùúàùë°\widehat{\nu}^{(t)} and yùë¶y with distribution Q‚Äã(y|ùü∂)ùëÑconditionalùë¶0Q(y|{\tt 0}), compute Œ¶‚Äã(ŒΩ^1(t),‚Ä¶,ŒΩ^l‚àí1(t);y)Œ¶superscriptsubscript^ùúà1ùë°‚Ä¶superscriptsubscript^ùúàùëô1ùë°ùë¶\Phi(\widehat{\nu}_{1}^{(t)},\dots,\widehat{\nu}_{l-1}^{(t)};y). The resulting quantity will have distribution ŒΩ(t+1)superscriptùúàùë°1\nu^{(t+1)}. Because of this description, they are also called ‚Äòrecursive distributional equations‚Äô.
