4.5 The Belief Propagation Threshold

Density evolution would not be such an useful tool if it could not be simulated efficiently. The idea is to estimate numerically the distributions of the density evolution variables {h(t),u(t)}superscript‚Ñéùë°superscriptùë¢ùë°\{h^{(t)},u^{(t)}\}. As already discussed this gives access to a number of statistics on BP decoding, such as the bit error rate Pb(t)superscriptsubscriptPbùë°{\rm P}_{{\rm b}}^{(t)} after tùë°t iterations in the large blocklength limit.

A possible approach consists in representing the distributions by samples of some fixed size. Within statistical physics this is sometimes called the population dynamics algorithm (and made its first appearance in the study of the localization transition on Cayley trees [46]). Although there exist more efficient alternatives in the coding context (mainly based on Fourier transform, see [49, 48]), we shall describe population dynamics because it is easily programmed.

Let us describe the algorithm within the setting of a general message passing decoder, cf. Eq.¬†(4.19). Given an integer ùí©‚â´1much-greater-thanùí©1{\cal N}\gg 1, one represent the messages distributions with two samples of size ùí©ùí©{\cal N}: ùîì(t)={ŒΩ1(t),‚Ä¶,ŒΩùí©(t)}superscriptùîìùë°superscriptsubscriptùúà1ùë°‚Ä¶superscriptsubscriptùúàùí©ùë°{\mathfrak{P}}^{(t)}=\{\nu_{1}^{(t)},\dots,\nu_{{\cal N}}^{(t)}\}, and ùîì^(t)={ŒΩ^1(t),‚Ä¶,ŒΩ^ùí©(t)}superscript^ùîìùë°superscriptsubscript^ùúà1ùë°‚Ä¶superscriptsubscript^ùúàùí©ùë°\widehat{\mathfrak{P}}^{(t)}=\{\widehat{\nu}_{1}^{(t)},\dots,\widehat{\nu}_{{\cal N}}^{(t)}\}. Such samples are used as proxy for the corresponding distributions. For instance, one would approximate an expectation as

ùîº‚Äãf‚Äã(ŒΩ(t))‚âà1ùí©‚Äã‚àëi=1ùí©f‚Äã(ŒΩi(t)).ùîºùëìsuperscriptùúàùë°1ùí©superscriptsubscriptùëñ1ùí©ùëìsubscriptsuperscriptùúàùë°ùëñ\displaystyle{\mathbb{E}}f(\nu^{(t)})\approx\frac{1}{{\cal N}}\sum_{i=1}^{{\cal N}}\,f(\nu^{(t)}_{i})\,. (4.24)

The populations are updated iteratively. For instance ùîì(t+1)superscriptùîìùë°1{\mathfrak{P}}^{(t+1)} is obtained from ùîì^(t)superscript^ùîìùë°\widehat{\mathfrak{P}}^{(t)} by generating ŒΩ1(t+1),‚Ä¶,ŒΩùí©(t+1)superscriptsubscriptùúà1ùë°1‚Ä¶superscriptsubscriptùúàùí©ùë°1\nu_{1}^{(t+1)},\dots,\nu_{{\cal N}}^{(t+1)} independently as follows. For each i‚àà[ùí©]ùëñdelimited-[]ùí©i\in[{\cal N}], draw indices b1‚Äã(i),‚Ä¶,bl‚Äã(i)subscriptùëè1ùëñ‚Ä¶subscriptùëèùëôùëñb_{1}(i),\dots,b_{l}(i) independently and uniformly at random from [ùí©]delimited-[]ùí©[{\cal N}], and generate yisubscriptùë¶ùëñy_{i} with distribution Q‚Äã(y|ùü∂)ùëÑconditionalùë¶0Q(y|{\tt 0}). An equivalent description consists in saying that we proceed as if ùîì^(t)superscript^ùîìùë°\widehat{\mathfrak{P}}^{(t)} exactly represents the distribution of u(t)superscriptùë¢ùë°u^{(t)} (which in this case would be discrete). If this was the case, the distribution of h(t+1)superscript‚Ñéùë°1h^{(t+1)} would be composed of |ùíú|‚ãÖùí©l‚àí1‚ãÖùíúsuperscriptùí©ùëô1|{\cal A}|\cdot{\cal N}^{l-1} Dirac deltas. In order not to overflow memory, the algorithm samples ùí©ùí©{\cal N} values from such a distribution. Empirically, estimates of the form (4.24) obtained through population dynamics have systematic errors of order ùí©‚àí1superscriptùí©1{\cal N}^{-1} and statistical errors of order ùí©‚àí1/2superscriptùí©12{\cal N}^{-1/2} with respect to the exact value.

In Fig.¬†15 we report the results of population dynamics simulations for two different LDPC ensembles, with respect to the BSC. We consider two performance measures: the bit error rate Pb(t)superscriptsubscriptPbùë°{\rm P}_{{\rm b}}^{(t)} and the bit conditional entropy H(t)superscriptùêªùë°H^{(t)}. The latter is defined as

H(t)=limN‚Üí‚àû1N‚Äã‚àëi=1Nùîº‚ÄãH‚Äã(Xi|ŒΩ¬Øi(t)),superscriptùêªùë°subscript‚ÜíùëÅ1ùëÅsuperscriptsubscriptùëñ1ùëÅùîºùêªconditionalsubscriptùëãùëñsuperscriptsubscript¬Øùúàùëñùë°\displaystyle H^{(t)}=\lim_{N\to\infty}\frac{1}{N}\sum_{i=1}^{N}{\mathbb{E}}\,H(X_{i}|\overline{\nu}_{i}^{(t)})\,, (4.25)

and encodes the uncertainty about bit xisubscriptùë•ùëñx_{i} after tùë°t BP iterations. It is intuitively clear that, as the algorithm progresses, the bit estimates improve and therefore Pb(t)superscriptsubscriptPbùë°{\rm P}_{{\rm b}}^{(t)} and H(t)superscriptùêªùë°H^{(t)} should be monotonically decreasing functions of the number of iterations. Further, they are expected to be monotonically increasing functions of the crossover probability pùëùp. Both statement can be easily checked on the above plots, and can be proved rigorously as well.

Since Pb(t)superscriptsubscriptPbùë°{\rm P}_{{\rm b}}^{(t)} is non-negative and decreasing in tùë°t, it has a finite limit

PbBP‚â°limt‚Üí‚àûPb(t),superscriptsubscriptPbBPsubscript‚Üíùë°superscriptsubscriptPbùë°\displaystyle{\rm P}_{{\rm b}}^{\mbox{\tiny BP}}\equiv\lim_{t\to\infty}{\rm P}_{{\rm b}}^{(t)}\,, (4.26)

which is itself non-decreasing in pùëùp. The limit curve PbBPsuperscriptsubscriptPbBP{\rm P}_{{\rm b}}^{\mbox{\tiny BP}} is estimated in Fig.¬†15 by choosing tùë°t large enough so that Pb(t)superscriptsubscriptPbùë°{\rm P}_{{\rm b}}^{(t)} is independent of tùë°t within the numerical accuracy.

Since PbBP=PbBP‚Äã(p)superscriptsubscriptPbBPsuperscriptsubscriptPbBPùëù{\rm P}_{{\rm b}}^{\mbox{\tiny BP}}={\rm P}_{{\rm b}}^{\mbox{\tiny BP}}(p) is a non-decreasing function of pùëùp, one can define the BP threshold

pd‚â°sup{p‚àà[0,1/2]:PbBP‚Äã(p)=0}.subscriptùëùdsupremumconditional-setùëù012superscriptsubscriptPbBPùëù0\displaystyle p_{\rm d}\equiv\sup\left\{\,p\in[0,1/2]\,:\,{\rm P}_{{\rm b}}^{\mbox{\tiny BP}}(p)=0\,\right\}\,. (4.27)

Analogous definitions can be provided for other channel families such as the BEC(œµ)italic-œµ(\epsilon). In general, the definition (4.27) can be extended to any family of BMS channels BMS(p)ùëù(p) indexed by a real parameter p‚ààIùëùùêºp\in I, I‚äÜ‚Ñùùêº‚ÑùI\subseteq{\mathbb{R}} being an interval (obviously the supsupremum\sup will be then taken over p‚ààIùëùùêºp\in I). The only condition is that the family is ‚Äòordered by physical degradation‚Äô. We shall not describe this concept formally, but limit ourselves to say that that pùëùp should be an ‚Äòhonest‚Äô noise parameter, in the sense that the channel worsen as pùëùp increases.

Analytical upper and lower bounds can be derived for pdsubscriptùëùdp_{\rm d}. In particular it can be shown that it is strictly larger than 00 (and smaller than 1/2121/2) for all LDPC ensembles with minimum variable degree at least 222. Numerical simulation of density evolution allows to determine it numerically with good accuracy. In Table 1 we report the results of a few such results.

Let us stress that the threshold pdsubscriptùëùdp_{\rm d} has an important practical meaning. For any p<pdùëùsubscriptùëùdp<p_{\rm d} one can achieve arbitrarily small bit error rate with high probability by just picking one random code from the ensemble LDPC and using BP decoding and running it for a large enough (but independent of the blocklength) number of iterations. For p>pdùëùsubscriptùëùdp>p_{\rm d} the bit error rate is asymptotically lower bounded by PbBP‚Äã(p)>0superscriptsubscriptPbBPùëù0{\rm P}_{{\rm b}}^{\mbox{\tiny BP}}(p)>0 for any fixed number of iterations. In principle it could be that after, let‚Äôs say nasuperscriptùëõùëén^{a}, a>0ùëé0a>0 iterations a lower bit error rate is achieved. However simulations show quite convincingly that this is not the case.

In physics terms the algorithm undergoes a phase transition at pdsubscriptùëùdp_{\rm d}. At first sight, such a phase transition may look entirely dependent on the algorithm definition and not ‚Äòuniversal‚Äô in any sense. As we will discuss in the next section, this is not the case. The phase transition at pdsubscriptùëùdp_{\rm d} is somehow intrinsic to the underlying measure Œº‚Äã(x¬Ø)ùúá¬Øùë•\mu(\underline{x}), and has a well studied counterpart in the theory of mean field disordered spin models.

Apart from the particular channel family, the BP threshold depends on the particular code ensemble, i.e. (for the case considered here) on the code ensemble. It constitutes therefore a primary measure of the ‚Äògoodness‚Äô of such a pair. Given a certain design rate RùëÖR, one would like to make pdsubscriptùëùdp_{\rm d} as large as possible. This has motivated the introduction of code ensembles that generalize the regular ones studied here (starting from ‚Äòirregular‚Äô ones). Optimized ensembles have been shown to allow for exceptionally good performances. In the case of the erasure channel, they allowed to saturate Shannon‚Äôs fundamental limit [27]. This is an important approach to the design of LDPC ensembles.

Let us finally mention that the BP threshold was defined in Eq.¬†(4.27) in terms of the bit error rate. One may wonder whether a different performance parameter may yield a different threshold. As long as such parameter can be written in the form 1N‚Äã‚àëif‚Äã(hi(t))1ùëÅsubscriptùëñùëìsuperscriptsubscript‚Ñéùëñùë°\frac{1}{N}\sum_{i}f(h_{i}^{(t)}) this is not the case. More precisely

pd=sup{p‚ààI:h(t)‚Üíd+‚àû},subscriptùëùdsupremumconditional-setùëùùêºsuperscript‚Üídsuperscript‚Ñéùë°\displaystyle p_{\rm d}=\sup\left\{\,p\in I\,:\,h^{(t)}\stackrel{{\scriptstyle{\rm d}}}{{\to}}+\infty\,\right\}\,, (4.28)

where, for the sake of generality we assumed the noise parameter to belong to an interval I‚äÜ‚Ñùùêº‚ÑùI\subseteq{\mathbb{R}}. In other words, for any p<pdùëùsubscriptùëùdp<p_{\rm d} the distribution of BP messages becomes a delta at plus infinity.

4.6 Belief Propagation versus MAP Decoding

So far we have seen that detailed predictions can be obtained for the performance of LDPC ensembles under message passing decoding (at least in the large blocklength limit). In particular the threshold noise for reliable communication is determined in terms of a distributional recursion (density evolution). This recursion can in turn be efficiently approximated numerically, leading to accurate predictions for the threshold.

It would be interesting to compare such predictions with the performances under optimal decoding strategies. Throughout this section we shall focus on symbol MAP decoding, which minimizes the bit error rate, and consider a generic channel family {BMS‚Äã(p)}BMSùëù\{{\rm BMS}(p)\} ordered121212Such that the channel worsen as pùëùp increases. Examples are the binary symmetric or binary erasure channels. by the noise parameter pùëùp.

Given an LDPC ensemble, let Pb(N)superscriptsubscriptPbùëÅ{\rm P}_{{\rm b}}^{(N)} be the expected bit error rate when the blocklength is NùëÅN. The MAP threshold pcsubscriptùëùcp_{\rm c} for such an ensemble can be defined as the largest (or, more precisely, the supremum) value of pùëùp such that limN‚Üí‚àûPb(N)=0subscript‚ÜíùëÅsuperscriptsubscriptPbùëÅ0\lim_{N\to\infty}{\rm P}_{{\rm b}}^{(N)}=0. In other words, for any p<pcùëùsubscriptùëùcp<p_{\rm c} one can communicate with an arbitrarily small error probability, by using a random code from the ensemble, provided NùëÅN is large enough.

By the optimality of MAP decoding, pd‚â§pcsubscriptùëùdsubscriptùëùcp_{\rm d}\leq p_{\rm c}. In coding theory some techniques have been developed to prove upper and lower bounds on pcsubscriptùëùcp_{\rm c} [19, 52]. In particular it is easy to find ensembles for which there exist a gap between the two thresholds (namely pd<pcsubscriptùëùdsubscriptùëùcp_{\rm d}<p_{\rm c} strictly). Consider for instance (k,l)ùëòùëô(k,l) regular ensembles with a fixed ratio l/k=1‚àíRùëôùëò1ùëÖl/k=1-R. It is then possible to show that, as k,l‚Üí‚àû‚Üíùëòùëôk,l\to\infty, the BP threshold goes to 00 while the MAP threshold approaches the Shannon limit.

This situation is somewhat unsatisfactory. The techniques used to estimate pdsubscriptùëùdp_{\rm d} and pcsubscriptùëùcp_{\rm c} are completely different. This is puzzling since the two thresholds can be extremely close and even coincide for some ensembles. Furthermore, we know that pd‚â§pcsubscriptùëùdsubscriptùëùcp_{\rm d}\leq p_{\rm c} by a general argument (optimality of MAP decoding), but this inequality is not ‚Äòbuilt in‚Äô the corresponding derivations. Finally, it would be interesting to have a sharp estimate for pcsubscriptùëùcp_{\rm c}.

It turns out that a sharp characterization of pcsubscriptùëùcp_{\rm c} can be obtained through statistical mechanics techniques [42, 58, 38]. The statistical mechanics result has been proved to be a rigorous upper bound for general code ensembles, and it is conjectured to be tight [39, 35].

The starting point is to consider the conditional entropy of the channel input x¬Ø¬Øùë•\underline{x} given the output y¬Ø¬Øùë¶\underline{y}, HN‚Äã(X¬Ø|Y¬Ø)subscriptùêªùëÅconditional¬Øùëã¬ØùëåH_{N}(\underline{X}|\underline{Y}). As shown in Eq.¬†(2.18) this is given by the expectation of the log partition function appearing in Eq.¬†(4.1) (apart from a trivial additive factor).

Let ùñøN=ùîº‚ÄãHN‚Äã(X¬Ø|Y¬Ø)/NsubscriptùñøùëÅùîºsubscriptùêªùëÅconditional¬Øùëã¬ØùëåùëÅ{\sf f}_{N}={\mathbb{E}}H_{N}(\underline{X}|\underline{Y})/N denote the entropy density averaged over the code ensemble. Intuitively speaking, this quantity allows to estimate the typical number of inputs with non-negligible probability for a given channel output. If ùñøNsubscriptùñøùëÅ{\sf f}_{N} is bounded away from 00 as N‚Üí‚àû‚ÜíùëÅN\to\infty, the typical channel output corresponds to an exponential number of (approximately) equally likely inputs. If on the other hand ùñøN‚Üí0‚ÜísubscriptùñøùëÅ0{\sf f}_{N}\to 0, the correct input has to be searched among a sub-exponential number of candidates. This leads us to identify131313A rigorous justification of this identification can be obtained using Fano‚Äôs inequality. the MAP threshold as the largest noise level such that ùñøN‚Üí0‚ÜísubscriptùñøùëÅ0{\sf f}_{N}\to 0 as N‚Üí‚àû‚ÜíùëÅN\to\infty.

The Bethe free energy provides a natural way to approximate log-partition functions on sparse graphs. It is known to be exact if the underlying graph is a tree and its stationary points are in correspondence with the fixed points of BP. In statistical physics terms, it is the correct variational formulation for the Bethe Peierls approximation. In random systems which are locally tree like, it is normally thought to provide the correct N‚Üí‚àû‚ÜíùëÅN\to\infty limit unless long range correlations set in. These are in turn described through ‚Äòreplica symmetry breaking‚Äô (see below).

As many mean field approximations, the Bethe approximation can be thought of as a way of writing the free energy as a function of a few correlation functions. These in turn coincide for with the fixed point conditions for belief propagation, cf. Eqs.¬†(4.11).

The Bethe free energy can be written as a function of the messages by plugging the expressions (4.31) into Eq.¬†(4.6). Using the fixed point equations, we get

Notice that the random variables uùë¢u, h‚Ñéh are constrained by Eq.¬†(4.32), which must be fulfilled in distributional sense. In other words uùë¢u, h‚Ñéh must form a fixed point of the density evolution recursion (4.20). Given this proviso, if the above assumptions are correct and the Bethe free energy is a good approximation for the log partition function one expects the conditional entropy per bit to be limN‚Üí‚àûùñøN=œïu,hsubscript‚ÜíùëÅsubscriptùñøùëÅsubscriptitalic-œïùë¢‚Ñé\lim_{N\to\infty}{\sf f}_{N}=\phi_{u,h}. This guess is supported by the following rigorous result.

Theorem 4.2.

If uùë¢u, h‚Ñéh are symmetric random variables satisfying the distributional identity u=datanh‚Äã{‚àèi=1k‚àí1tanh‚Å°hi}superscriptdùë¢atanhsuperscriptsubscriptproductùëñ1ùëò1subscript‚Ñéùëñu\stackrel{{\scriptstyle{\rm d}}}{{=}}{\rm atanh}\left\{\prod_{i=1}^{k-1}\tanh h_{i}\right\}, then

It is natural to conjecture that the correct limit is obtained by optimizing the above lower bound, i.e.

limN‚Üí‚àûùñøN=supu,hœïu,h,subscript‚ÜíùëÅsubscriptùñøùëÅsubscriptsupremumùë¢‚Ñésubscriptitalic-œïùë¢‚Ñé\displaystyle\lim_{N\to\infty}{\sf f}_{N}=\sup_{u,h}\,\phi_{u,h}\,, (4.37)

In other words the couple uùë¢u, h‚Ñéh must be a density evolution fixed point.

This conjecture has indeed been proved in the case of communication over the binary erasure channel for a large class of LDPC ensembles (including, for instance, regular ones).

The expression (4.37) is interesting because it bridges the analysis of BP and MAP decoding. For instance, it is immediate to show that it implies pd‚â§pcsubscriptùëùdsubscriptùëùcp_{\rm d}\leq p_{\rm c}.

  • Exercise 4: This exercise aims at proving the last statement.

    • (a)ùëé(a)

      Recall that u,h=+‚àûùë¢‚Ñéu,h=+\infty constitute a density evolution fixed point for any noise level. Show that œïh,u=0subscriptitalic-œï‚Ñéùë¢0\phi_{h,u}=0 on such a fixed point.

    • (b)ùëè(b)

      Assume that, if any other fixed point exists, then density evolution converges to it (this can indeed be proved in great generality).

    • (c)ùëê(c)

      Deduce that pd‚â§pcsubscriptùëùdsubscriptùëùcp_{\rm d}\leq p_{\rm c}.

Evaluating the expression (4.37) implies an a priori infinite dimensional optimization problem. In practice good approximations can be obtained through the following procedure:

  1. 1.

    Initialize h‚Ñéh, uùë¢u to a couple of symmetric random variables h(0)superscript‚Ñé0h^{(0)}, u(0)superscriptùë¢0u^{(0)}.

  2. 2.

    Implement numerically the density evolution recursion (4.20) and iterate it until an approximate fixed point is attained.

  3. 3.

    Evaluate the functional œïu,hsubscriptitalic-œïùë¢‚Ñé\phi_{u,h} on such a fixed point, after enforcing u=datanh‚Äã{‚àèi=1k‚àí1tanh‚Å°hi}superscriptdùë¢atanhsuperscriptsubscriptproductùëñ1ùëò1subscript‚Ñéùëñu\stackrel{{\scriptstyle{\rm d}}}{{=}}{\rm atanh}\left\{\prod_{i=1}^{k-1}\tanh h_{i}\right\} exactly.

The above procedure can be repeated for several different initializations u(0)superscriptùë¢0u^{(0)}, h(0)superscript‚Ñé0h^{(0)}. The largest of the corresponding values of œïu,hsubscriptitalic-œïùë¢‚Ñé\phi_{u,h} is then picked as an estimate for limN‚Üí‚àûùñøNsubscript‚ÜíùëÅsubscriptùñøùëÅ\lim_{N\to\infty}{\sf f}_{N}.

While his procedure is not guaranteed to exhaust all the possible density evolution fixed points, it allows to compute a sequence of lower bounds to the conditional entropy density. Further, one expects a small finite number of density evolution fixed points. In particular, for regular ensembles and p>pdùëùsubscriptùëùdp>p_{\rm d}, a unique (stable) fixed point is expected to exist apart from the no-error one u,h=+‚àûùë¢‚Ñéu,h=+\infty. In Table 2 we present the corresponding MAP thresholds for a few regular ensembles.

For further details on these results, and complete proofs, we refer to [39]. Here we limit ourselves to a brief discussion why the conjecture (4.37) is expected to hold from a statistical physics point of view.

The expression (4.37) corresponds to the ‚Äòreplica symmetric ansatz‚Äô from the present problem. This usually breaks down if some form of long-range correlation (‚Äòreplica symmetry breaking‚Äô) arises in the measure Œº‚Äã(‚ãÖ)ùúá‚ãÖ\mu(\,\cdot\,). This phenomenon is however not expected to happen in the case at hand. The technical reason is that the so-called Nishimori condition holds for Œº‚Äã(‚ãÖ)ùúá‚ãÖ\mu(\,\cdot\,) [38]. This condition generally holds for a large family of problems arising in communications and statistical inference. While Nishimori condition does not provide an easy proof of the conjecture (4.37), it implies a series of structural properties of Œº‚Äã(‚ãÖ)ùúá‚ãÖ\mu(\,\cdot\,) that are commonly regarded as incompatible with replica symmetry breaking.

Replica symmetry breaking is instead necessary to describe the structure of ‚Äòmetastable states‚Äô [17]. This can be loosely described as very deep local minima in the energy landscape introduced in Section¬†4.1. Here ‚Äòvery deep‚Äô means that Œò‚Äã(N)ŒòùëÅ\Theta(N) bit flips are necessary to lower the energy (number of unsatisfied parity checks) when starting from such minima. As the noise level increases, such local minima become relevant at the so called ‚Äòdynamic phase transition‚Äô. It turns out that the critical noise for this phase transition coincides with the BP threshold pdsubscriptùëùdp_{\rm d}. In other words the double phase transition at pdsubscriptùëùdp_{\rm d} and pcsubscriptùëùcp_{\rm c} is completely analogous to what happens in the mean field theory of structural glasses (see for instance Parisi‚Äôs lectures at this School). Furthermore, this indicates that pdsubscriptùëùdp_{\rm d} has a ‚Äòstructural‚Äô rather than purely algorithmic meaning.

5 Belief Propagation Beyond Coding Theory

The success of belief propagation as an iterative decoding procedure has spurred a lot of interest in its application to other statistical inference tasks.

A simple formalization for this family of problems is provided by factor graphs. One is given a factor graph G=(V,F,E)ùê∫ùëâùêπùê∏G=(V,F,E) with variable nodes VùëâV, function nodes FùêπF, and edges Eùê∏E and considers probability distributions that factorize accordingly

Œº‚Äã(x¬Ø)=1Z‚Äã‚àèa‚ààFœàa‚Äã(x¬Ø‚àÇa).ùúá¬Øùë•1ùëçsubscriptproductùëéùêπsubscriptùúìùëésubscript¬Øùë•ùëé\displaystyle\mu(\underline{x})=\frac{1}{Z}\,\prod_{a\in F}\psi_{a}(\underline{x}_{\partial a})\,. (5.1)

Here the variables xisubscriptùë•ùëñx_{i} take values in a generic finite alphabet ùí≥ùí≥{\cal X}, and the compatibility functions œàa:ùí≥‚àÇa‚Üí‚Ñù+:subscriptùúìùëé‚Üísuperscriptùí≥ùëésubscript‚Ñù\psi_{a}:{\cal X}^{\partial a}\to{\mathbb{R}}_{+} encode dependencies among them. The prototypical problem consists in computing marginals of the distribution Œº‚Äã(‚ãÖ)ùúá‚ãÖ\mu(\,\cdot\,), e.g.,

Œºi‚Äã(xi)‚â°‚àëx¬Ø‚àºiŒº‚Äã(x¬Ø).subscriptùúáùëñsubscriptùë•ùëñsubscriptsubscript¬Øùë•similar-toabsentùëñùúá¬Øùë•\displaystyle\mu_{i}(x_{i})\equiv\sum_{\underline{x}_{\sim i}}\mu(\underline{x})\,. (5.2)

Belief propagation can be used to accomplish this task in a fast and distributed (but not necessarily accurate) fashion. The general update rules read

ŒΩi‚Üía(t+1)‚Äã(xi)‚àù‚àèb‚àà‚àÇi\aŒΩ^b‚Üíi(t)‚Äã(xi),ŒΩ^a‚Üíi(t)‚Äã(xi)‚àù‚àë{xj}œàa‚Äã(x¬Ø‚àÇa)‚Äã‚àèj‚àà‚àÇa\iŒΩj‚Üía(t)‚Äã(xj).formulae-sequenceproportional-tosuperscriptsubscriptùúà‚Üíùëñùëéùë°1subscriptùë•ùëñsubscriptproductùëè\ùëñùëésubscriptsuperscript^ùúàùë°‚Üíùëèùëñsubscriptùë•ùëñproportional-tosuperscriptsubscript^ùúà‚Üíùëéùëñùë°subscriptùë•ùëñsubscriptsubscriptùë•ùëósubscriptùúìùëésubscript¬Øùë•ùëésubscriptproductùëó\ùëéùëñsubscriptsuperscriptùúàùë°‚Üíùëóùëésubscriptùë•ùëó\displaystyle\nu_{i\to a}^{(t+1)}(x_{i})\propto\prod_{b\in\partial i\backslash a}\widehat{\nu}^{(t)}_{b\to i}(x_{i})\,,\;\;\;\;\;\widehat{\nu}_{a\to i}^{(t)}(x_{i})\propto\sum_{\{x_{j}\}}\psi_{a}(\underline{x}_{\partial a})\prod_{j\in\partial a\backslash i}\nu^{(t)}_{j\to a}(x_{j})\,. (5.3)

Messages are then used to estimate local marginals as follows

ŒΩ¬Øi(t+1)‚Äã(xi)superscriptsubscript¬Øùúàùëñùë°1subscriptùë•ùëñ\displaystyle\overline{\nu}_{i}^{(t+1)}(x_{i}) ‚àùproportional-to\displaystyle\propto ‚àèb‚àà‚àÇiŒΩ^b‚Üíi(t)‚Äã(xi).subscriptproductùëèùëñsubscriptsuperscript^ùúàùë°‚Üíùëèùëñsubscriptùë•ùëñ\displaystyle\prod_{b\in\partial i}\widehat{\nu}^{(t)}_{b\to i}(x_{i})\,. (5.4)

The basic theoretical question is of course to establish a relation, if any between Œºi‚Äã(‚ãÖ)subscriptùúáùëñ‚ãÖ\mu_{i}(\,\cdot\,) and ŒΩ¬Øi‚Äã(‚ãÖ)subscript¬Øùúàùëñ‚ãÖ\overline{\nu}_{i}(\,\cdot\,).

As an example, we shall consider satisfiability [23]. Given NùëÅN Boolean variables xisubscriptùë•ùëñx_{i}, i‚àà{1,‚Ä¶,N}ùëñ1‚Ä¶ùëÅi\in\{1,\dots,N\}, xi‚àà{True,False}subscriptùë•ùëñTrueFalsex_{i}\in\{{\rm True},\,{\rm False}\}, a formula is the logical expression obtained by taking the AND of MùëÄM clauses. Each clause is the logical OR of a subset of the variables or their negations. As an example, consider the formula (here x¬Øisubscript¬Øùë•ùëñ\overline{x}_{i} denotes the negation of xisubscriptùë•ùëñx_{i})

(x¬Ø1‚à®x¬Ø2‚à®x¬Ø4)‚àß(x1‚à®x¬Ø2)‚àß(x2‚à®x4‚à®x5)‚àß(x1‚à®x2‚à®x¬Ø5)‚àß(x1‚à®x¬Ø3‚à®x5).subscript¬Øùë•1subscript¬Øùë•2subscript¬Øùë•4subscriptùë•1subscript¬Øùë•2subscriptùë•2subscriptùë•4subscriptùë•5subscriptùë•1subscriptùë•2subscript¬Øùë•5subscriptùë•1subscript¬Øùë•3subscriptùë•5\displaystyle{(\overline{x}_{1}\vee\overline{x}_{2}\vee\overline{x}_{4})}{\wedge}{(x_{1}\vee\overline{x}_{2})}{\wedge}{(x_{2}\vee x_{4}\vee x_{5})}{\wedge}{(x_{1}\vee x_{2}\vee\overline{x}_{5})}{\wedge}{(x_{1}\vee\overline{x}_{3}\vee x_{5})}\,. (5.5)

An assignment of the NùëÅN variables satisfies the formula if, for each of the clause, at least one of the involved literals (i.e. either the variables or their negations) evaluates to True.

A satisfiability formula admits a natural factor graph representation where each clause is associated to a factor node and each variable to a variable node. An example is shown in Fig.¬†16. Admitting that the formula has at least one satisfying assignment, it is natural to associate to a ‚Ñ±‚Ñ±{\cal F} the uniform measure over such assignments Œº‚Ñ±‚Äã(x¬Ø)subscriptùúá‚Ñ±¬Øùë•\mu_{{\cal F}}(\underline{x}). It is easy to realize that such a distribution takes the form (5.1) where the compatibility function œàa‚Äã(x¬Ø‚àÇa)subscriptùúìùëésubscript¬Øùë•ùëé\psi_{a}(\underline{x}_{\partial a}) takes value 111 if the assignment x¬Ø¬Øùë•\underline{x} satisfies clause aùëéa and 00 otherwise.

Satisfiability, i.e., the problem of finding a solution to a satisfiability formula or proving that it is usatisfiable, is one of the prototypical NP-complete problems. Given a satisfiability formula, computing marginals with respect to the associated distribution Œº‚Ñ±‚Äã(‚ãÖ)subscriptùúá‚Ñ±‚ãÖ\mu_{{\cal F}}(\,\cdot\,) is relevant for tasks such as counting the number of solutions of ‚Ñ±‚Ñ±{\cal F} or sampling them uniformly. These are well known ##\#-P complete problems.141414The notation ##\#-P refers to the hardness classification for counting problems.

The currently best algorithms for solving random instances for the KùêæK-SAT problem are based on a variant of BP, which is called survey propagation [11, 33, 11].

5.1 Proving Correctness through Correlation Decay

A simple trick to bound the error incurred by BP consists in using the correlation decay properties [1, 57] of the measure Œº‚Äã(‚ãÖ)ùúá‚ãÖ\mu(\,\cdot\,). Let i‚àà{1,‚Ä¶,N}ùëñ1‚Ä¶ùëÅi\in\{1,\dots,N\} be a variable index and denote by x¬Øtsubscript¬Øùë•ùë°\underline{x}_{t} the set of variables sitting on nodes at distance tùë°t from iùëñi. Further, denote by x¬Ø‚â•tsubscript¬Øùë•absentùë°\underline{x}_{\geq t} the set of variables whose distance from iùëñi is at least tùë°t. Then the local structure of the probability distribution (5.1)

Œºi‚Äã(xi)=‚àëx¬Ø‚â•tŒº‚Äã(xi|x¬Ø‚â•t)‚ÄãŒº‚Äã(x¬Ø‚â•t)=‚àëx¬ØtŒº‚Äã(xi|x¬Øt)‚ÄãŒº‚Äã(x¬Øt).subscriptùúáùëñsubscriptùë•ùëñsubscriptsubscript¬Øùë•absentùë°ùúáconditionalsubscriptùë•ùëñsubscript¬Øùë•absentùë°ùúásubscript¬Øùë•absentùë°subscriptsubscript¬Øùë•ùë°ùúáconditionalsubscriptùë•ùëñsubscript¬Øùë•ùë°ùúásubscript¬Øùë•ùë°\displaystyle\mu_{i}(x_{i})=\sum_{\underline{x}_{\geq t}}\mu(x_{i}|\underline{x}_{\geq t})\mu(\underline{x}_{\geq t})=\sum_{\underline{x}_{t}}\mu(x_{i}|\underline{x}_{t})\mu(\underline{x}_{t})\,. (5.6)

Let ùñ°i‚Äã(t)subscriptùñ°ùëñùë°{\sf B}_{i}(t) denote the subgraph induced by nodes whose distance from iùëñi is at most tùë°t, and ‚àÇùñ°i‚Äã(t)subscriptùñ°ùëñùë°\partial{\sf B}_{i}(t) its boundary (nodes whose distance from iùëñi is exactly tùë°t). As an example of such error estimates, we shall consider random kùëòk-satisfiability [16]. This is a standard model to generate ‚Äòsynthetic‚Äô satisfiability formulae. 6 Belief Propagation Beyond the Binary Symmetric Channel

So far we have considered mainly the case of transmission over BMS channels, our reference example being the BSC. There are many other channel models that are important and are encountered in practical situations. Fortunately, it is relatively straightforward to extend the previous techniques and statements to a much larger class, and we review a few such instances in this section.

6.1 Binary Memoryless Symmetric Channels

In order to keep the notation simple, we assumed channel output to belong to a finite alphabet ùíúùíú{\cal A}. In our main example, the BSC, we had ùíú={ùü∂,ùü∑}ùíú01{\cal A}=\{{\tt 0},{\tt 1}\}. But in fact all results are valid for a wider class of binary memoryless symmetric (BMS) channels. One can prove that there is no loss of generality in assuming the output alphabet to be the real line ‚Ñù‚Ñù{\mathbb{R}} (eventually completed with ‚Ñù¬Ø=‚Ñù‚à™{¬±‚àû}¬Ø‚Ñù‚Ñùplus-or-minus\overline{{\mathbb{R}}}={\mathbb{R}}\cup\{\pm\infty\}).

Let y¬Ø=(y1,‚Ä¶,yN)¬Øùë¶subscriptùë¶1‚Ä¶subscriptùë¶ùëÅ\underline{y}=(y_{1},\dots,y_{N}) be the vector of channel outputs on input x¬Ø=(x1,‚Ä¶,xN)¬Øùë•subscriptùë•1‚Ä¶subscriptùë•ùëÅ\underline{x}=(x_{1},\dots,x_{N}). For a BMS the input is binary, i.e. x¬Ø‚àà{ùü∂,ùü∑}N¬Øùë•superscript01ùëÅ\underline{x}\in\{{\tt 0},{\tt 1}\}^{N}. Further the channel is memoryless, i.e. the probability density of getting y¬Ø‚àà‚Ñù¬ØN¬Øùë¶superscript¬Ø‚ÑùùëÅ\underline{y}\in\overline{{\mathbb{R}}}^{N} at output when the input is x¬Ø¬Øùë•\underline{x}, is

Q‚Äã(y¬Ø|x¬Ø)ùëÑconditional¬Øùë¶¬Øùë•\displaystyle Q(\underline{y}|\underline{x}) =‚àèt=1NQ‚Äã(yt|xt).absentsuperscriptsubscriptproductùë°1ùëÅùëÑconditionalsubscriptùë¶ùë°subscriptùë•ùë°\displaystyle=\prod_{t=1}^{N}Q(y_{t}|x_{t}).

Finally, the symmetry property can be written without loss of generality, as Q‚Äã(yt|xt=ùü∑)=Q‚Äã(‚àíyt|xt=ùü∂)ùëÑconditionalsubscriptùë¶ùë°subscriptùë•ùë°1ùëÑconditionalsubscriptùë¶ùë°subscriptùë•ùë°0Q(y_{t}|x_{t}={\tt 1})=Q(-y_{t}|x_{t}={\tt 0}).

One of the most important elements in this class is the additive white Gaussian noise (AWGN) channel, defined by

ytsubscriptùë¶ùë°\displaystyle y_{t} =xt+zt,t‚àà{1,‚Ä¶,N},formulae-sequenceabsentsubscriptùë•ùë°subscriptùëßùë°ùë°1‚Ä¶ùëÅ\displaystyle=x_{t}+z_{t}\,,\;\;\;\;\;\;t\in\{1,\dots,N\}\,,

where the sequence {zt}subscriptùëßùë°\{z_{t}\} is i.i.d. consisting of Gaussian random variables with mean zero and variance œÉ2superscriptùúé2\sigma^{2}. It is common in this setting to let xisubscriptùë•ùëñx_{i} take values in {+1,‚àí1}11\{+1,-1\} instead of {ùü∂,ùü∑}01\{{\tt 0},{\tt 1}\} as we have assumed so far. The AWGNC transition probability density function is therefore

Q‚Äã(yt|xt)=12‚ÄãœÄ‚ÄãœÉ2‚Äãe‚àí(y‚àíx)22‚ÄãœÉ2.ùëÑconditionalsubscriptùë¶ùë°subscriptùë•ùë°12ùúãsuperscriptùúé2superscriptùëísuperscriptùë¶ùë•22superscriptùúé2\displaystyle Q(y_{t}|x_{t})=\frac{1}{\sqrt{2\pi\sigma^{2}}}\;e^{-\frac{(y-x)^{2}}{2\sigma^{2}}}\,.

The AWGNC is the basic model of transmission of an electrical signal over a cable (here the noise is due to thermal noise in the receiver) and it is also a good model of a wireless channel in free space (e.g., transmission from a satellite).

Although the class of BMS channels is already fairly large, it is important in practice to go beyond it. The extension to the non-binary case is quite straightforward and so we will not discuss it in detail. The extension to channels with memory or the asymmetric case are more interesting and so we present them in the subsequent two sections.

6.2 Channels With Memory

Loosely speaking, in a memoryless channel the channel acts on each transmitted bit independently. In a channel with memory, on the other hand, the channel acts generally on the whole block of input bits together. An important special case of a channel with memory is if the channel can be modeled as a Markov chain, taking on a sequence of ‚Äúchannel states.‚Äù Many physical channels posses this property and under this condition the message-passing approach can still be applied. For channels with memory there are two problems. First, we need to determine the capacity of the channel. Second, we need to devise efficient coding schemes that achieve rates close to this capacity. It turns out that both problems can be addressed in a fairly similar framework. Rather than discussing the general case we will look at a simple but typical example.

Let us start by computing the information rate/capacity of channels with memory, assuming that the channel has a Markov structure. As we discussed in Section¬†2.5 in the setting of BMS channels, the channel capacity can be expressed as the difference of two entropies, namely as H‚Äã(X)‚àíH‚Äã(X|Y)ùêªùëãùêªconditionalùëãùëåH(X)-H(X|Y). Here, XùëãX denotes the binary input and YùëåY denotes the observation at the output of the channel whose input is XùëãX. Given two random variables XùëãX, YùëåY, this entropy difference is called the mutual information and is typically denoted by I‚Äã(X;Y)=H‚Äã(X)‚àíH‚Äã(X;Y)ùêºùëãùëåùêªùëãùêªùëãùëåI(X;Y)=H(X)-H(X;Y).

A general channel, is defined by a channel transition probability Q‚Äã(y1N|x1N)ùëÑconditionalsuperscriptsubscriptùë¶1ùëÅsuperscriptsubscriptùë•1ùëÅQ(y_{1}^{N}|x_{1}^{N}) (here and below x1Nsuperscriptsubscriptùë•1ùëÅx_{1}^{N} denotes the vector (x1,‚Ä¶,xN)subscriptùë•1‚Ä¶subscriptùë•ùëÅ(x_{1},\dots,x_{N})). In order to define a joint distribution of the input and output vectors, we have to prescribe a distribution on the channel input, call it p‚Äã(x1N)ùëùsuperscriptsubscriptùë•1ùëÅp(x_{1}^{N}). The channel capacity is obtained by maximizing the mutual information over all possible distributions of the input, and eventually taking the N‚Üí‚àû‚ÜíùëÅN\to\infty limit. In formulae

ùô≤‚Äã(Q)=limN‚Üí‚àûsupp‚Äã(‚ãÖ)I‚Äã(X1N;Y1N)/N.ùô≤ùëÑsubscript‚ÜíùëÅsubscriptsupremumùëù‚ãÖùêºsuperscriptsubscriptùëã1ùëÅsuperscriptsubscriptùëå1ùëÅùëÅ\displaystyle{\tt C}(Q)=\lim_{N\to\infty}\sup_{p(\,\cdot\,)}\,I(X_{1}^{N};Y_{1}^{N})/N\,.

For BMS channels it is possible to show that the maximum occurs for the uniform prior: p‚Äã(x1N)=1/2Nùëùsuperscriptsubscriptùë•1ùëÅ1superscript2ùëÅp(x_{1}^{N})=1/2^{N}. Under this distribution, I‚Äã(X1N;Y1N)/Nùêºsuperscriptsubscriptùëã1ùëÅsuperscriptsubscriptùëå1ùëÅùëÅI(X_{1}^{N};Y_{1}^{N})/N is easily seen not to depend on NùëÅN and we recover the expression in Sec.¬†2.5.

For channels with memory we have to maximize the mutual information over all possible distributions over {ùü∂,ùü∑}Nsuperscript01ùëÅ\{{\tt 0},{\tt 1}\}^{N} (a space whose dimension is exponential in NùëÅN), and take the limit N‚Üí‚àû‚ÜíùëÅN\to\infty. An easier task is to choose a convenient input distribution p‚Äã(‚ãÖ)ùëù‚ãÖp(\,\cdot\,) and then compute the corresponding mutual information in the N‚Üí‚àû‚ÜíùëÅN\to\infty limit:

Iùêº\displaystyle I =limN‚Üí‚àûI‚Äã(X1N;Y1N)/N.absentsubscript‚ÜíùëÅùêºsuperscriptsubscriptùëã1ùëÅsuperscriptsubscriptùëå1ùëÅùëÅ\displaystyle=\lim_{N\rightarrow\infty}I(X_{1}^{N};Y_{1}^{N})/N\,. (6.1)

Remarkably, this quantity has an important operational meaning. It is the largest rate at which we can transmit reliably across the channel using a coding scheme such that the resulting input distribution matches p‚Äã(‚ãÖ)ùëù‚ãÖp(\,\cdot\,).

To be definite, assume that the channel is defined by a state sequence {œÉt}t‚â•0subscriptsubscriptùúéùë°ùë°0\{\sigma_{t}\}_{t\geq 0}, taking values in a finite alphabet, such that the joint probability distribution factors in the form

p‚Äã(x1n,y1n,œÉ0n)=p‚Äã(œÉ0)‚Äã‚àèi=1np‚Äã(xi,yi,œÉi‚à£œÉi‚àí1).ùëùsuperscriptsubscriptùë•1ùëõsuperscriptsubscriptùë¶1ùëõsuperscriptsubscriptùúé0ùëõùëùsubscriptùúé0superscriptsubscriptproductùëñ1ùëõùëùsubscriptùë•ùëñsubscriptùë¶ùëñconditionalsubscriptùúéùëñsubscriptùúéùëñ1p(x_{1}^{n},y_{1}^{n},\sigma_{0}^{n})=p(\sigma_{0})\prod_{i=1}^{n}p(x_{i},y_{i},\sigma_{i}\mid\sigma_{i-1}). (6.2)

We will further assume that the transmitted bits (x1,‚ãÖ,xN)subscriptùë•1‚ãÖsubscriptùë•ùëÅ(x_{1},\cdot,x_{N}) are iid uniform in {ùü∂,ùü∑}01\{{\tt 0},{\tt 1}\}. The factor graph corresponding to (6.2) is shown in Fig.¬†17. It is drawn in a somewhat different way compared to the factor graphs we have seen so far. Note that in the standard factor graph corresponding to this factorization all variable nodes have degree two. In such a case it is convenient not to draw the factor graph as a bipartite graph but as a standard graph in which the nodes correspond to the factor nodes and the edges correspond to the variable nodes (which have degree two and therefore connect exactly two factors). Such a graphical representation is also known as normal graph or as Forney-style factor graph (FSFG), in honor of Dave Forney who introduced them [15].

Let us now look at a concrete example.

In this model we assume that the channel quality is evolving according to a Markov chain. In the simplest case there are exactly two states, and this is the original Gilbert-Elliott channel (GEC) model. More precisely, consider the two-state Markov chain depicted in Fig.¬†18.     which encodes the transition probabilities between the states (the columns indicate the present state and the rows the next state). Define the steady state probability vector p=(pG,pB)ùëùsubscriptùëùGsubscriptùëùBp=(p_{\text{G}},p_{\text{B}}), i.e., the vector which fulfills P‚ÄãpT=pTùëÉsuperscriptùëùùëásuperscriptùëùùëáPp^{T}=p^{T}. If we consider e.g. the state Gùê∫G then the detailed balance condition reads pG‚Äãg¬Ø=pB‚Äãb¬ØsubscriptùëùG¬ØùëîsubscriptùëùB¬Øùëèp_{\text{G}}\bar{g}=p_{\text{B}}\bar{b}. More generally, let us assume that we have sùë†s states, s‚àà‚Ñïùë†‚Ñïs\in{\mathbb{N}}, and that the channel in state iùëñi, i‚àà[s]ùëñdelimited-[]ùë†i\in[s], is the BSC(œµi)subscriptitalic-œµùëñ(\epsilon_{i}). Let PùëÉP be the s√ósùë†ùë†s\times s matrix encoding the transition probabilities between these states. Let pùëùp denote the steady-state probability distribution vector. If (I‚àíPT+E)ùêºsuperscriptùëÉùëáùê∏(I-P^{T}+E) is invertible then a direct check shows that p=e‚Äã(I‚àíPT+E)‚àí1ùëùùëísuperscriptùêºsuperscriptùëÉùëáùê∏1p=e(I-P^{T}+E)^{-1}, where eùëíe is the all-one vector of length sùë†s, IùêºI is the s√ósùë†ùë†s\times s identity matrix and Eùê∏E is the s√ósùë†ùë†s\times s all-one matrix.

    Note that the state sequence is ergodic as long as the Markov chain is irreducible (i.e. there is a path of strictly positive probability from any state to any other state) and aperiodic (i.e. there there exists such a path for any number of steps large enough). In the original Gilbert-Elliot model this is true as long as 0<g,b<1formulae-sequence0ùëîùëè10<g,b<1.

Now that we can compute the maximal rate at which we can transmit reliably, let us consider coding. The symbol MAP decoder is

=argmaxxi‚Äã‚àë{xj,j‚â†i}p‚Äã(œÉ0)‚Äã‚àèj=1Np‚Äã(xj,yj,œÉj‚à£œÉj‚àí1)‚ÄãùïÄ‚Ñ≠‚Äã(x1N).absentsubscriptargmaxsubscriptùë•ùëñsubscriptsubscriptùë•ùëóùëóùëñùëùsubscriptùúé0superscriptsubscriptproductùëó1ùëÅùëùsubscriptùë•ùëósubscriptùë¶ùëóconditionalsubscriptùúéùëósubscriptùúéùëó1subscriptùïÄ‚Ñ≠superscriptsubscriptùë•1ùëÅ\displaystyle=\text{argmax}_{x_{i}}\sum_{\{x_{j},\,j\neq i\}}p(\sigma_{0})\prod_{j=1}^{N}p(x_{j},y_{j},\sigma_{j}\mid\sigma_{j-1}){\mathbb{I}}_{{\mathfrak{C}}}(x_{1}^{N}).

In words, the FSFG in Fig.¬†17 describes also the factorization for the message-passing decoder if we add to it the factor nodes describing the definition of the code. As always, this factor graph together with the initial messages stemming from the channel completely specify the message-passing rules, except for the message-passing schedule. Let us agree that we alternate one round of decoding with one round of channel estimation. No claim as to the optimality of this scheduling rule is made.

Notice that the correlations induced by the markovian structure of the channel are in general short ranged in time. This is analogous to what happens with a one-dimensional spin model, whose correlation length is always finite (at non-zero temperature). A good approximation to the above message passing schedule is therefore obtained by a ‚Äòwindowed‚Äô decodes. This means that the state at time tùë°t is estimated only of the basis of observations between time t‚àíRùë°ùëÖt-R and t+Rùë°ùëÖt+R, for some finite RùëÖR.

Assuming windowed decoding for channel estimation, it is not hard to show that after a fixed number of iterations, the decoding neighborhood is again asymptotically tree-like. In the case of the GEC the channel symmetry can be used to reduce to the all-zero codeword. Therefore, we can employ the technique of density evolution to determine thresholds and to optimize the ensembles.

  • Example 6:[GEC: State Estimation]

    For the case of transmission over the GEC the iterative decoder implicitly also estimates the state of the channel. Let us demonstrate this by means of the following example. We pick a GEC with three states. Let

    P=(0.990.0050.020.0050.990.020.0050.0050.96),ùëÉ0.990.0050.020.0050.990.020.0050.0050.96\displaystyle P=\left(\begin{array}[]{ccc}0.99&0.005&0.02\\ 0.005&0.99&0.02\\ 0.005&0.005&0.96\end{array}\right),

    which has a steady state probability vector of p‚âà(0.4444,0.4444,0.1112)ùëù0.44440.44440.1112p\approx(0.4444,0.4444,0.1112). Finally, let the channel parameters of the BSC in these three states be (œµ1,œµ2,œµ3)‚âà(0.01,0.11,0.5)subscriptitalic-œµ1subscriptitalic-œµ2subscriptitalic-œµ30.010.110.5(\epsilon_{1},\epsilon_{2},\epsilon_{3})\approx(0.01,0.11,0.5). This corresponds to an average error probability of œµavg=‚àëi=13pi‚Äãœµi‚âà0.108889subscriptitalic-œµavgsuperscriptsubscriptùëñ13subscriptùëùùëñsubscriptitalic-œµùëñ0.108889\epsilon_{\text{avg}}=\sum_{i=1}^{3}p_{i}\epsilon_{i}\approx 0.108889. Using the methods described above, the capacity of this channel (assuming uniform inputs) can be computed to be equal to C‚âà0.583ùê∂0.583C\approx 0.583 bits per channel use. This is markedly higher than 1‚àíh‚Äã(œµavg)‚âà0.5034441‚Ñésubscriptitalic-œµavg0.5034441-h(\epsilon_{\text{avg}})\approx 0.503444, which is the capacity of the BSC(œµavg)subscriptitalic-œµavg(\epsilon_{\text{avg}}). The last channel is the channel which we experience if we ignore the Markov structure.

    Fig.¬†19 shows the evolution of the densities for an optimized ensemble of rate r‚âà0.5498ùëü0.5498r\approx 0.5498. The pictures on the right correspond to the messages which are passed from the part of the factor graph which estimates the state towards the part of the factor graph which describes the code. These messages therefore can be interpreted as the current estimate of the state the channel is in at a given point in time. Note that after 10 iterations 5 clear peaks emerge. These peaks are at ¬±log‚Å°(0.99/0.01)‚âà¬±4.595plus-or-minus0.990.01plus-or-minus4.595\pm\log(0.99/0.01)\approx\pm 4.595, ¬±log‚Å°(0.9/0.1)‚âà¬±2.197plus-or-minus0.90.1plus-or-minus2.197\pm\log(0.9/0.1)\approx\pm 2.197, ¬±log‚Å°(0.5/0.5)=0plus-or-minus0.50.50\pm\log(0.5/0.5)=0. They correspond to the received likelihoods in the three possible channel states. In other words, the emergence of the peaks shows that at this stage the system has identified the channel states with high reliability. This is quite pleasing. Although the channel state is not known to the receiver and can not be observed directly, in the region where the iterative decoder works reliably it also automatically estimates the channel state with high confidence.

Although we only looked a very particular example it is quite typical of the general situation: as long as the channel memory can be described by a Markov chain the factor graph approach applies and we can use message-passing schemes to construct efficient coding schemes [14, 4, 21, 22, 25, 43].

6.3 Asymmetric Channels - The Z Channel

Let us now consider the second generalization, namely the case of non-symmetric channels.

Consider the channel depicted on the right of Fig.¬†1. For obvious reasons it is called the Z channel (ZC). This channel has binary input and it is memoryless but it is not symmetric. Nevertheless, essentially the same type of analysis which we performed in Section¬†4 can be applied to this case as well. Symmetry is therefore a nice property to have but it is not essential.

Consider the capacity of this channel. Since the channel is not symmetric the capacity is not necessarily given by the mutual information between channel input and channel output for a uniform input distribution of the input. We must instead maximize the mutual information over the input distribution. Since the channel is memoryless, it can be assumed that the input is given by a sequence of i.i.d. bernoulli variables. Assuming that p‚Äã(xi=ùü∂)=Œ±ùëùsubscriptùë•ùëñ0ùõºp(x_{i}={\tt 0})=\alpha, the output distribution is

(p‚Äã(yi=ùü∂),p‚Äã(yi=ùü∑))ùëùsubscriptùë¶ùëñ0ùëùsubscriptùë¶ùëñ1\displaystyle(p(y_{i}={\tt 0}),p(y_{i}={\tt 1})) =(Œ±‚Äãp¬Ø,1‚àíŒ±‚Äãp¬Ø),absentùõº¬Øùëù1ùõº¬Øùëù\displaystyle=(\alpha\bar{p},1-\alpha\bar{p}),

so that the mutual information IŒ±‚Äã(X;Y)subscriptùêºùõºùëãùëåI_{\alpha}(X;Y) for a fixed Œ±ùõº\alpha is equal to

IŒ±‚Äã(X;Y)=H‚Äã(Y)‚àíH‚Äã(Y‚à£X)=h‚Äã(Œ±‚Äãp¬Ø)‚àíŒ±‚Äãh‚Äã(p).subscriptùêºùõºùëãùëåùêªùëåùêªconditionalùëåùëã‚Ñéùõº¬Øùëùùõº‚ÑéùëùI_{\alpha}(X;Y)=H(Y)-H(Y\mid X)=h(\alpha\bar{p})-\alpha h(p). (6.5)

Some calculus reveals that the optimal choice of Œ±ùõº\alpha is

Œ±‚Äã(p)=pp/p¬Ø1+p¬Ø‚Äãpp/p¬Ø,ùõºùëùsuperscriptùëùùëù¬Øùëù1¬Øùëùsuperscriptùëùùëù¬Øùëù\alpha(p)=\frac{p^{p/\bar{p}}}{1+\bar{p}p^{p/\bar{p}}}, (6.6)

so that

CZC‚Äã(p)=h‚Äã(Œ±‚Äã(p)‚Äãp¬Ø)‚àíŒ±‚Äã(p)‚Äãh‚Äã(p).subscriptùê∂ZCùëù‚Ñéùõºùëù¬Øùëùùõºùëù‚ÑéùëùC_{\text{ZC}(p)}=h(\alpha(p)\bar{p})-\alpha(p)h(p).

Fig.¬†20 compares CZC‚Äã(p)subscriptùê∂ZCùëùC_{\text{ZC}(p)} with IŒ±=12‚Äã(X;Y)subscriptùêºùõº12ùëãùëåI_{\alpha=\frac{1}{2}}(X;Y), i.e., it compares the capacity with the transmission rate which is achievable with uniform input distribution.

This is important and surprising ‚Äì only little is lost by insisting on an uniform input distribution: the rate which is achievable by using a uniform input distribution is at least a fraction 12‚Äãe‚Äãln‚Å°(2)‚âà0.92412ùëí20.924\frac{1}{2}e\ln(2)\approx 0.924 of capacity over the entire range of pùëùp (with equality when pùëùp approaches one). Even more fortunate, from this perspective the Z channel is the extremal case [32, 54]: the information rate of any binary-input memoryless channel when the input distribution is the uniform one is at least a fraction 12‚Äãe‚Äãln‚Å°(2)12ùëí2\frac{1}{2}e\ln(2) of its capacity. From the above discussion we conclude that, when dealing with asymmetric channels, not much is lost if we use a binary linear coding scheme (inducing a uniform input distribution).

Consider the density evolution analysis. Because of the lack of symmetry we can no longer make the all-one codeword assumption. Therefore, it seems at first that we have to analyze the behavior of the decoder with respect to each codeword. Fortunately this is not necessary. First note that, since we consider an ensemble average, only the type of the codeword matters. More precisely, let us say that a codeword has type œÑùúè\tau if the fraction of zeros is œÑùúè\tau. For x¬Ø‚àà‚Ñ≠¬Øùë•‚Ñ≠\underline{x}\in{\mathfrak{C}}, let œÑ‚Äã(x¬Ø)ùúè¬Øùë•\tau(\underline{x}) be its type. Let us assume that we use an LDPC ensemble whose dominant type is one-half. This means that ‚Äúmost‚Äù codewords contain roughly as many zeros as one. Although it is possible to construct degree-distributions which violate this constraint, ‚Äúmost‚Äù degree distributions do fulfill it. Under this assumption there exists some strictly positive constant Œ≥ùõæ\gamma such that

‚Ñô‚Äã{œÑ‚Äã(x¬Ø)‚àâ[1/2‚àíŒ¥/n,1/2+Œ¥/n]}‚â§e‚àíŒ¥2‚ÄãŒ≥,‚Ñôùúè¬Øùë•12ùõøùëõ12ùõøùëõsuperscriptùëísuperscriptùõø2ùõæ{\mathbb{P}}\left\{\tau(\underline{x})\not\in[1/2-\delta/\sqrt{n},1/2+\delta/\sqrt{n}]\right\}\leq e^{-\delta^{2}\gamma}\,, (6.7)

where the probability is with respect to a uniformly random codeword x¬Ø¬Øùë•\underline{x}. We can therefore analyze the performance of such a system in the following way: determine the error probability assuming that the type of the transmitted codeword is ‚Äúclose‚Äù to the typical one. Since sublinear changes in the type do not figure in the density analysis, this task can be accomplished by a straightforward density evolution analysis. Now add to this the probability that the type of a random codeword deviates significantly from the typical one. The second term can be made arbitrarily small (see right hand side of (6.7)) by choosing Œ¥ùõø\delta sufficiently large.

We summarize: if we encounter a non-symmetric channel and we are willing to sacrifice a small fraction of capacity then we can still use standard LDPC ensembles (which impose a uniform input distribution) to transmit at low complexity. If it is crucial that we approach capacity even closer, a more sophisticated approach is required. We can combine LDPC ensembles with non-linear mappers which map the uniform input distribution imposed by linear codes into a non-uniform input distribution at the channel input in order to bring the mutual information closer to capacity. For a detailed discussion on coding for the ZùëçZ-channel we refer the reader to [34, 59, 5].

7 Open Problems

Let us close by reviewing some of the most important open challenges in the channel coding problem.

7.1 Order of Limits

Density evolution computes the limit

limt‚Üí‚àûlimN‚Üí‚àûùîº‚Å°[Pb(N,t)].subscript‚Üíùë°subscript‚ÜíùëÅùîºsuperscriptsubscriptPbùëÅùë°\displaystyle\lim_{t\rightarrow\infty}\lim_{N\rightarrow\infty}\operatorname{\mathbb{E}}[{\rm P}_{{\rm b}}^{(N,t)}].

In words we determined the limiting performance of an ensemble under a fixed number of iterations as the blocklength tends to infinity and then let the number of iterations tend to infinity. As we have seen, this limit is relatively easy to compute. What happens if the order of limits is exchanged, i.e., how does the limit

limN‚Üí‚àûlimt‚Üí‚àûùîº‚Å°[Pb(N,t)]subscript‚ÜíùëÅsubscript‚Üíùë°ùîºsuperscriptsubscriptPbùëÅùë°\displaystyle\lim_{N\rightarrow\infty}\lim_{t\rightarrow\infty}\operatorname{\mathbb{E}}[{\rm P}_{{\rm b}}^{(N,t)}]

behave? This limit is closer in spirit to the typical operation in practice: for each fixed length the BP decoder continues until no further progress is achieved. We are interested in the limiting performance as the blocklength tends to infinity.

For the BEC it is known that the two limits coincide. If we combine this with the fact that for the BEC the performance is a monotone function in the number of iterations (any further iteration can only make the result better) then we get the important observation that regardless of how we take the limit (jointly or sequentially), as long as both the blocklength as well as the number of iterations tend to infinity we get the same result. From a practical perspective this is comforting to know: it shows that we can expect a certain robustness of the performance with respect to the details of the operation.

It is conjectured that the same statement holds for general BMS channels. Unfortunately, no proof is known.

7.2 Finite-Length Performance

The threshold gives an indication of the asymptotic performance: for channel parameters which are better than the threshold sufficiently long codes allow transmission at an arbitrarily low probability of bit error. If, on the other hand, we transmit over a channel which has a parameter that is worse than the threshold then we can not hope to achieve a low probability of error. This is an important insight but from a practical perspective we would like to know how fast the finite-length performance approaches this asymptotic limit. There can be many different ensembles that all have the same asymptotic performance but that might have a substantially different finite-length behavior. Can we predict which one we should choose a priori without having to resort to simulations? The typical convergence of the performance to the asymptotic limit is shown in Fig.¬†21. The points correspond to simulation results whereas the solid curves correspond to a general scaling conjecture [2]. Roughly speaking, this scaling conjecture states that around the threshold the error probability behaves as follows: Let the channel be parameterized by œµitalic-œµ\epsilon with increasing œµitalic-œµ\epsilon indicating a worsening of the channel. Let œµdsubscriptitalic-œµd\epsilon_{\rm d} be the BP threshold, and define z=n‚Äã(œµ‚àíœµd)ùëßùëõitalic-œµsubscriptitalic-œµdz=\sqrt{n}(\epsilon-\epsilon_{\rm d}). Then for zùëßz fixed and nùëõn tending to infinity we have

PB‚Äã(n,œµ)subscriptPBùëõitalic-œµ\displaystyle{\rm P}_{{\rm B}}(n,\epsilon) =Œ¶‚Äã(z/Œ±)‚Äã(1+o‚Äã(1)),absentŒ¶ùëßùõº1ùëú1\displaystyle=\Phi\left(z/\alpha\right)\bigl{(}1+o(1)\bigr{)},

where Œ¶‚Äã(‚ãÖ)Œ¶‚ãÖ\Phi(\,\cdot\,) is the error function (i.e. Œ¶‚Äã(x)Œ¶ùë•\Phi(x) is the probability that a standard normal random variable is smaller than xùë•x), and Œ±ùõº\alpha is a constant which depends on the channel as well as on the channel.

For the BEC this scaling law has been shown to be correct [2]. In fact, even a refined version is known [13]: define z=n‚Äã(œµ‚àíœµd+Œ≤‚Äãn‚àí23)ùëßùëõitalic-œµsubscriptitalic-œµdùõΩsuperscriptùëõ23z=\sqrt{n}(\epsilon-\epsilon_{\rm d}+\beta n^{-\frac{2}{3}}) where Œ≤ùõΩ\beta is a constant depending on the ensemble. Then for zùëßz fixed and nùëõn tending to infinity we have

PB‚Äã(n,œµ)subscriptPBùëõitalic-œµ\displaystyle{\rm P}_{{\rm B}}(n,\epsilon) =Q‚Äã(z/Œ±)‚Äã(1+O‚Äã(n‚àí1/3)).absentùëÑùëßùõº1ùëÇsuperscriptùëõ13\displaystyle=Q\left(z/\alpha\right)\bigl{(}1+O\bigl{(}n^{-1/3}\bigr{)}\bigr{)}.

For general channels on the other hand the problem is largely open. If proved to be correct, finite length scaling laws could be used as a tool for an efficient finite-length optimization.

7.3 Capacity-Achieving Codes

For the most part we have taken the point of view that we are given an ensemble of codes and a family of channels and we would like to determine the performance of this combination. For instance, the most fundamental question is to determine the threshold noise for such a code/decoder combination. Hopefully this threshold is close to the best possible as determined by Shannon‚Äôs capacity formula.

But we can take a more active point of view. Given a family of channels how should we choose the ensemble in order for the threshold noise to be as high as possible. In other words, can we approach the capacity of the channel?

For the BSC this question has been answered by Luby, Mitzenmacher, Shokrollahi, Spielman, and Steman in [27]. These authors showed that by a suitable choice of the degree distribution one can approach the capacity arbitrarily closely. More precisely, in order to approach capacity up to a fraction Œ¥ùõø\delta the average degree has to grow like log‚Å°(1/Œ¥)1ùõø\log(1/\delta) and this is the best possible. For general channels it is not known whether capacity can be achieved. Although the resolution of this problem will most likely only have a small practical implication it is without doubt the most important open theoretical problem in this area.

Appendix A A Generating Function Calculation

We want to compute the number of ways of picking nùëõn distinct objects from MùëÄM groups each containing kùëòk objects, in such a way that the number of selected elements in each group is even. Let us denote this number by Cnsubscriptùê∂ùëõC_{n}. The result of this computation is used in Section¬†3.3, where we claimed the result to be Cn=ùñºùóàùñæùñøùñø‚Äã[qk‚Äã(z)M,zn]subscriptùê∂ùëõùñºùóàùñæùñøùñøsubscriptùëûùëòsuperscriptùëßùëÄsuperscriptùëßùëõC_{n}={\sf coeff}[q_{k}(z)^{M},z^{n}] (in that case n=l‚Äãwùëõùëôùë§n=lw).

First notice that given m1,‚Ä¶,mMsubscriptùëö1‚Ä¶subscriptùëöùëÄm_{1},\dots,m_{M} all even, the number of ways of choosing m1subscriptùëö1m_{1} objects from the first group, m2subscriptùëö2m_{2} from the second, etc is

(km1)‚Äã(km2)‚Äã‚ãØ‚Äã(kmM).binomialùëòsubscriptùëö1binomialùëòsubscriptùëö2‚ãØbinomialùëòsubscriptùëöùëÄ\displaystyle\binom{k}{m_{1}}\binom{k}{m_{2}}\cdots\binom{k}{m_{M}}\,. (A.1)

The desired number Cnsubscriptùê∂ùëõC_{n} is the sum of this quantity over the even numbers m1,‚ãØ,mnsubscriptùëö1‚ãØsubscriptùëöùëõm_{1},\cdots,m_{n} such that m1,‚Ä¶,mM‚àà{0,‚Ä¶‚Äãk}subscriptùëö1‚Ä¶subscriptùëöùëÄ0‚Ä¶ùëòm_{1},\dots,m_{M}\in\{0,\dots k\} and m1+‚ãØ+mM=nsubscriptùëö1‚ãØsubscriptùëöùëÄùëõm_{1}+\dots+m_{M}=n. The corresponding generating function is

C‚Äã(z)‚â°‚àën=0k‚ÄãMCn‚Äãzn=‚àëm1‚Äã‚Ä¶‚Äãmneven(km1)‚Äã(km2)‚Äã‚ãØ‚Äã(kmM)‚Äãzm1‚Äã‚ãØ‚ÄãzmN,ùê∂ùëßsuperscriptsubscriptùëõ0ùëòùëÄsubscriptùê∂ùëõsuperscriptùëßùëõsubscriptsuperscriptevensubscriptùëö1‚Ä¶subscriptùëöùëõbinomialùëòsubscriptùëö1binomialùëòsubscriptùëö2‚ãØbinomialùëòsubscriptùëöùëÄsuperscriptùëßsubscriptùëö1‚ãØsuperscriptùëßsubscriptùëöùëÅ\displaystyle C(z)\equiv\sum_{n=0}^{kM}C_{n}z^{n}=\sum^{\mbox{\tiny even}}_{m_{1}\dots m_{n}}\binom{k}{m_{1}}\binom{k}{m_{2}}\cdots\binom{k}{m_{M}}z^{m_{1}}\cdots z^{m_{N}}\,, (A.2)

the sum being restricted over even integers m1,‚Ä¶,mM‚àà{0,‚Ä¶‚Äãk}subscriptùëö1‚Ä¶subscriptùëöùëÄ0‚Ä¶ùëòm_{1},\dots,m_{M}\in\{0,\dots k\}. We now notice that the sum factorizes yielding
